code_quote:
Okay. General collaboration means engaging in a conversation, in a dialog, to understand each other needs and interest, and then finding the way to go get to a point where the needs and interests of all the parties are met. It is a process where you communicate and negotiate, and develop some consensus about what is best for all the parties.
Francisco:
That's a pretty general definition, but that's the way I understand it. It's an iterative process. I mean, it's hard to get to that point at the first attempt, so you have to go back and forth until you feel comfortable to engage in collaboration with someone else.
Then if you're in the weak part of the collaboration, you have to work a little bit extra, struggle to find the point at which your interests and needs can be satisfied collaboration.

Well, I mean that's the idea that I normally use when I pursue any collaboration with someone, but it is not the usual way. I mean, being here on the US-Mexico border where there are so many [inaudible] in services and power, normally collaboration start in a different point is many times, very often is like something that is kind of imposed on you by someone that has more [inaudible] power.

At the end of the day, the collaboration is not as symmetrical, or even is kind of you are in the lower side of the relationship. But anyway, you engage because there is something for you on that relationship.

So in comparison to your solo projects or your solo initiatives, what would you say that is the key characteristic that differentiates solo projects versus collaborative projects?
Francisco:
Oh, well, I mean for me is ... How do I say it? There is this complementarity. I mean, there are things that you cannot do by yourself, that you need the expert needs, the resources, understanding, the relationship with someone else. Then you find someone that can provide all those things, and then you engage in collaboration.
Francisco:
Normally those are larger projects, the ones that you can do by yourself, alone. Normally in this particular context, which I do most of my collaboration, they are also more complex projects. Also, projects that have a different vision of all the things that you want to accomplish.
Francisco:
I mean, I can do a lot of the things that I do collaborate in by myself. I think so, but everything will be harder for me to accomplish the things I'm pursuing if I didn't have the support of my colleagues in Mexico now.

How did you meet your Mexican colleagues?
Francisco:
Okay. Well, there are many circumstances. I mean, I'll give you an example. I'm working right now on a project that is looking at issues of innovation in the US-Mexico border. The focus is Arizona and Sonora. We wanted to know, for example, how ... How do you say that in English? How pervasive, how generalized is the idea of innovation in universities and in the region on both sides of the border?
Francisco:
So that required doing interviews with researchers and students; we had the students and some people in government on both sides of the border. Because I am bilingual I can go and talk to people in the US and in Mexico, but it's easier for me, for example, to ask one of my colleagues, that I work with them for a long time, to help me in that project.
Francisco:
They will, for example, give me access to people that I normally won't have access in government, because even when I am Mexican, I am representing a US university. So I don't have the [inaudible 00:09:10], I don't have the presence, I don't have the connection that my colleagues from Mexico have. So, I can still do the interviews on the Mexican side, but as I said, it is going to be harder.
Francisco:
These are examples of a project I'm doing in collaboration with colleagues in Mexico, with which I collaborated in the past. These are all relationships. But also because you are engaged in these bi-national projects, people identify you as someone that can be the partner for Mexicans wanting to do something in the US. So you start developing new connections with [inaudible] as you work.
Francisco:
That's happened to me, for example, recently when someone approached me because they want to study the attitudes of residents of Arizona toward migration, and in general the perception of the way the Mexican government is handling border issues. It's old, and it's new, but anyway, it's connected with the work that we do.

Because I am bilingual I can go and talk to people in the US and in Mexico, but it's easier for me, for example, to ask one of my colleagues, that I work with them for a long time, to help me in that project.
Francisco:
They will, for example, give me access to people that I normally won't have access in government, because even when I am Mexican, I am representing a US university. So I don't have the [inaudible 00:09:10], I don't have the presence, I don't have the connection that my colleagues from Mexico have. So, I can still do the interviews on the Mexican side, but as I said, it is going to be harder.

These are examples of a project I'm doing in collaboration with colleagues in Mexico, with which I collaborated in the past. These are all relationships. But also because you are engaged in these bi-national projects, people identify you as someone that can be the partner for Mexicans wanting to do something in the US. So you start developing new connections with [inaudible] as you work.
Francisco:
That's happened to me, for example, recently when someone approached me because they want to study the attitudes of residents of Arizona toward migration, and in general the perception of the way the Mexican government is handling border issues. It's old, and it's new, but anyway, it's connected with the work that we do.

A variety of things. I mean, a variety of things. It's kind of crazy because as a result of your work on border, or as a person that is engaged in collaboration, a lot of people start coming to you looking for help or looking for support in many, many different things.
Francisco:
I'm working, for example, in a project looking at issues of accessibility to public parks in cities in the US and Mexico, and the impact of accessibility of parks on health behavior, exercise and physical activity. I'm working on this project on innovation. I'm working on a different project with colleagues in Brazil and in Venezuela, looking at issues of how border activity impact the function and the form of border towns in the Brazilian-Paraguay border, and the Colombia-Venezuela border, relative to what is happening in the US-Mexico border.

A variety of things. I mean, a variety of things. It's kind of crazy because as a result of your work on border, or as a person that is engaged in collaboration, a lot of people start coming to you looking for help or looking for support in many, many different things.
Francisco:
I'm working, for example, in a project looking at issues of accessibility to public parks in cities in the US and Mexico, and the impact of accessibility of parks on health behavior, exercise and physical activity. I'm working on this project on innovation. I'm working on a different project with colleagues in Brazil and in Venezuela, looking at issues of how border activity impact the function and the form of border towns in the Brazilian-Paraguay border, and the Colombia-Venezuela border, relative to what is happening in the US-Mexico border.
So it's a lot of things that is really exciting, really interesting. Projects that can only be done when you work in collaboration with someone that is on the other side of the border line.

It's a mix of things. Obviously is your own academic interests, which I mean, I'm a border planner, and I'm really excited when someone come and ask me to engage in these projects. It's also the institutional context where you are that drives you to engage. For example, in ASU, there has been an effort to increase the opportunities for engagement in international research for professionals and students. So I see that as an opportunity for me to advance on my own interests.
Francisco:
It's also the fact that, in my case for example, I'm currently the President of the Association for Borderlands Studies, which is a large academic organization. So that also create space for me to engage in these collaborative projects.
Francisco:
So it's [inaudible 00:13:59], it's institutional. It's sometimes hard to differentiate one being from the other because sometimes you find yourself pushing for change in your own university, so the university can become more open to this type of collaboration. So I would say that is my impression with that as it is pushing me to create conditions within my own university to being more open to global cooperation in academic models.

It depends on the project. For example, one thing I've been doing in the last four years is the creation of a theme that we called the Arizona-Sonora Interuniversity Alliance. What we are trying to do is to create a platform that facilitate collaboration across the border between US and Mexican universities in this part of the world. That's something that I initiated.
Francisco:
I remember myself going to University of Sonora, Colegio Sonora, CIAD and other higher education institutions in the area, knocking on the door of the Director of International Partnerships, going and knocking on the door of the director of the university, and telling them about the interests of my university and my school to develop a stronger connection with his or her university.
Francisco:
Sometimes people don't pay too much attention to you, but you have to insist. You have to be persistent and understand, as I said before, there is not, unless you attempt it, you will really attract the attention and then support of these people. You have to go back and talk to them, and convince them, persuade them that what you are pursuing is of their own benefit and on the benefit of your university. That you aren't doing this just because it is fun, but because there is a social impact that you want to produce as a result of this collaboration.
Francisco:
In this case for example, I initiated this in 2015. I was main director of a program that is called the Program for Transborder Communities, and I decided that the best way to make this program successful was developing these connections with Mexican universities. So that was the motivation and the way I did it. I went like a Babylonian [Spanish 00:17:18], knocking the door and trying to convince people that we were potentially a good partner for them.
Francisco:
We were competing with all the universities. I mean, ASU is pretty much active in collaboration with Mexico and globally, but in regard to Mexico, the University of Arizona, which is in Tucson, they have a stronger presence than us. So I was aware that I have to be as good as the University of Arizona in order to develop that presence in Mexico.
Francisco:
So this is a very large project. Since I started that we have signed some general collaboration agreements. We have had a couple of [inaudible] of universities meet and discuss the opportunities for exchange in research and education. It's a really big effort that I initiated in 19 ... in 2015, I'm sorry.
Francisco:
There are other things. There's smaller ones like, for example, a project in which I'm involved in the same region but in a smaller scale, because in order to see this in [inaudible] where basically I was just trying to replicate what I did with the alliance in that part of the world. I thought I could with some universities in Baja California, neighboring state, and initiate some small projects, nothing really big, in the area of [Hjel] and in Colombian development.

Sometimes people don't pay too much attention to you, but you have to insist. You have to be persistent and understand, as I said before, there is not, unless you attempt it, you will really attract the attention and then support of these people. You have to go back and talk to them, and convince them, persuade them that what you are pursuing is of their own benefit and on the benefit of your university. That you aren't doing this just because it is fun, but because there is a social impact that you want to produce as a result of this collaboration.

Which other organization? Any other organization from Mexico? I am thinking CONACYT, or Minister of Education for Mexico, or in the US, in that project that you are mentioning.
Francisco:
Well, in the alliance we are using local resources mostly. For example, ASU allocated some funding to support these efforts. While we are doing this through seed grants, through research seed grants. We are supporting projects that focus on issues of development pertaining to the Arizona ... the border region. We convince Mexican universities, for example, to create a singular parallel fund. So the University of Sonora, Colegio Sonora, and CIAD, and more recently Colegio from [Paranorque] and the University of Arizona, they decided to allocate some funding to support research from Mexico that want to do projects involving Arizona faculty. So we are not using CONACYT or NSF. Funding is just local resources.
Francisco:
Our hope is that once we demonstrate that the effort we are doing is productive, is impactful, CONACYT will say, "Okay, here are some money you can use to keep promoting your idea." That's our hope, because for ASU for example, this is an investment. They are seeing this as an initial investment. So the funding is going to be available for a year and a half, an extra year and a half, and after that we have to find a way to keep funding our activities.
Francisco:
In the case of the [inaudible] as I said, that is smaller, is a corporation, is a private corporation who is supporting the effort. The innovation study that I mentioned before, this is something that is being supported by the government of the state of Sonora. The parks and physical activity project, that has funding from CONACYT, but is small compared to-
Roxanna:
Compared to, yes.
Francisco:
... other things we are doing.

We convince Mexican universities, for example, to create a singular parallel fund. So the University of Sonora, Colegio Sonora, and CIAD, and more recently Colegio from [Paranorque] and the University of Arizona, they decided to allocate some funding to support research from Mexico that want to do projects involving Arizona faculty. So we are not using CONACYT or NSF. Funding is just local resources.

That's our hope, because for ASU for example, this is an investment. They are seeing this as an initial investment. So the funding is going to be available for a year and a half, an extra year and a half, and after that we have to find a way to keep funding our activities.

Yeah, I mean, it's easier with Mexico because I am Mexican and because I know the region very well. I have these connections, but definitely I will be interested in doing something like this somewhere else.

So the selection of Mexico comes from your familiarity with the country?
Francisco:
Yes, I was born here in Mexico. I always live in the border region. The reason I'm in ASU is because the work I did on the border. But I mean, as time passed and through other platforms, I think I'm now more interested and more well prepared to engage in collaboration with other countries, not only Mexico.
Francisco:
Actually, when I initiated this idea of the alliance, I was able to develop some agreements of collaboration with two universities on Europe, with Italy, with the University of Torino, and also with the University of Bergamo. We signed agreements of collaboration. We had some ideas about things that we wanted to do together, but it's a little bit harder. It's a little bit harder. It's easier for me to focus and [inaudible] accomplish here in the US-Mexico border.

The language obviously. My knowledge of the Mexican institutional culture. The fact that I used to work in Mexican universities. The proximity. I mean it's Tempe, where I work, is two hours and a half from the border. Then there is this idea that even when there is a border dividing Sonora and Arizona, they are part of the same region, the same states. So there is a strong identity that transcends the border, and that justify some of the efforts that we are supporting through this initiative. So it's a combination of things. As I said, it's the context, but also individual factor that explain what makes easy for me to engage in these type of areas.
Roxanna:
The other way around, what factors have impeded or making the collaboration a little bit harder?
Francisco:
Mm-hmm (affirmative).
Francisco:
Well, I think in my case, I mean you can have a bit individual, personal level and understanding of why this is important. That understanding can be the driver of your effort. Then if you really want to accomplish something, you have to convince people around you that what you are proposing is a good idea. ASU, that means sometimes it can be difficult. I mean, not everybody is aware of the relevance of collaboration for the development of the region, or the solution of many of the problems of the region in the Hjel environment, urban planning, or whatever, economic development.
Francisco:
Also, I think because ASU is three hours from the border and between is the University of Arizona, some people in my university will think, "Okay, let's leave that to the University of Arizona. That's not our area to be involved. We have a less competitive position relative to the University of Arizona, so let's not waste our resources in something that is going to be harder for us to accomplish."
Francisco:
So I believe that in the border, someone may think okay, because their current political environment, it might not be a good idea to try to do things with Mexico. But on the contrary, my opinion, that's an incentive. It's something that really push you to keep working with Mexico, because you understand how important it is to develop information and knowledge, and educate people, politician, policy makers about the importance of the relationship with Mexico for the US society and economy.

In that note, how would you qualify, or how interested or supportive is your institution concerning the US-Mexican collaboration?
Francisco:
I think it's growing. It's growing, I think, fast. It's not only as a result of my work. I have other colleagues with connections with the issues with Mexico and Latin America that have been also promoting the idea of a stronger connection with Mexico and Latin America.
Francisco:
My president, Michael Crow, is coming to Hermosillo, which is the capital city of the state of Sonora in January the 7th to meet with the governor and the [Spanish] in the public universities in the area. That's a very good sign. I'm hoping that that will really propel the work I'm doing through my program in the region. Then the university has an office that is promoting some initiative with Mexico. The [Garter] College is also really interested in connecting with Mexican universities.
Francisco:
So it's becoming more and more prominent, but we're still really behind, I mean, relative to other universities that I mentioned before. For me, the reference in terms of collaboration with Mexico in this part of the work is the University of Arizona in Tucson, they are doing very interesting things.
Roxanna:

In that note, how would you qualify, or how interested or supportive is your institution concerning the US-Mexican collaboration?
Francisco:
I think it's growing. It's growing, I think, fast. It's not only as a result of my work. I have other colleagues with connections with the issues with Mexico and Latin America that have been also promoting the idea of a stronger connection with Mexico and Latin America.

That's a very good sign. I'm hoping that that will really propel the work I'm doing through my program in the region. Then the university has an office that is promoting some initiative with Mexico. The [Garter] College is also really interested in connecting with Mexican universities.
Francisco:
So it's becoming more and more prominent, but we're still really behind, I mean, relative to other universities that I mentioned before. For me, the reference in terms of collaboration with Mexico in this part of the work is the University of Arizona in Tucson, they are doing very interesting things.
Roxanna:

Let's see. I think that we have to work more on that. I normally bring students to Mexico with me. Every semester I have my class, I literally force my students to come to Mexico. I have noticed that some of them are really appreciative of the opportunity of learning this about Mexico, but some students feel a little bit just weird, struggle to accept the idea of coming to Mexico. One of the things that we normally face here, for example, in terms of a change, it's very easy for Mexican students to cross the border and spend a week or a semester, or even their full graduate studies in Arizona. But convincing American students to come and do the same in Mexican universities, that's really hard.
Francisco:
I hear, for example, from people in the University of Sonora, that they are not able to attract American students. They receive some students from Latin America, from Colombia, from Brazil, but rarely receive any students from the US. I guess it's a combination of things, but one very important factor is the concern about security in Mexico. I mean, the last time I was here with my students, at least three of them excused themselves from participating in the field trip to Mexico because their parents didn't give permission for them to travel with me to Mexico.

How about your academics? Are they interested in collaborating with Mexico?
Francisco:
Yes, I think so. I think so. I mean, you have to give them information. You have to support them. For a lot of them the idea of collaborating with Mexican scholars is really, really attractive, but they are worried about the practicalities of language, the practicalities of how do you handle, for example, projects in Mexico administratively, or how do you manage, for example, funding in a bi-national setting. There are also concerns about security. Obviously they are less important than with the students.

May I ask about your department chair? What is his or her perception, or their perception, concerning the collaboration between the US and Mexico? How supportive-
Francisco:
Yeah, I think they're supportive. They have been very supportive really. No complaint about that. My school is ... the Liberal School is the School of Transborder Studies. So the implication there is that we need to work across the border. So for us, collaborating with Mexican scholars, bringing students from Mexico to Arizona is really, really critical. So we're doing that all the time, and the dean of the college and the sheriff of my department, all of them have been very, very supportive of this.

May I ask about your department chair? What is his or her perception, or their perception, concerning the collaboration between the US and Mexico? How supportive-
Francisco:
Yeah, I think they're supportive. They have been very supportive really. No complaint about that. My school is ... the Liberal School is the School of Transborder Studies. So the implication there is that we need to work across the border. So for us, collaborating with Mexican scholars, bringing students from Mexico to Arizona is really, really critical. So we're doing that all the time, and the dean of the college and the sheriff of my department, all of them have been very, very supportive of this.

In ideal conditions, or if you had the power to change the institutional conditions, what would be those conditions that would strengthen your collaboration with Mexico, Mexican partners?
Francisco:
I mean, obviously to do what I do, you need time. When you have, for example, a full teaching role where you don't have administrative support, and you don't have funding for travel, and you don't have the administrative flexibility ... Flexibility is part. So if I were to change something, I believe that my university will have to create conditions and mechanisms to facilitate this type of work. So that type of support is really, really essential, otherwise it's complicated for anyone to engage in collaboration.

For example, when I was trying to develop this alliance, the Arizona-Sonora Interuniversity Alliance, I mean, we have to go through a lot of protocol. We have to use boilerplate general collaboration agreement, went through the council in ASU, checked with the lawyers in the Mexican side. You had to be very careful with the language, the things that you commit. Then the signing of the agreements was really cumbersome. Sometimes they don't want to sign up til the other side sign. That's crazy because you have to start some place. So negotiating that part of the protocol can be daunting.

I don't know. It's sort of complicated, but I mean, once you have gone through the whole process, what you have created is a mechanism that facilitate others to engage in collaboration. So I mean, [Spanish] we said in Mexico, [Spanish 00:42:15], no? If the thing you want to accomplish is big, you have to be ready to deal with complex things like dealing with [inaudible 00:42:27], and lawyers, and rules that sometimes you don't know.

For example, with my case, I had to learn a lot because I was not engaged in [inaudible 00:42:44], because once you start trying to do something, you realize that the people that is supposed to be well informed about procedures are [inaudible 00:42:56]. Sometimes you are asking them to do things that they were never asked to do. So they have to do that, start looking very carefully to their tools, their bureaucratic tools, and doing adjustments and creating new protocols, new rules. It's like making a very heavy machinery to start moving, because what you are doing is new. That happened to me here in Arizona State University, and obviously when you are doing projects that involve another person, your friend, your colleague, it's easier.

I mean, it's really common. In this part of the US, it's really, really common, but it varies from university to university. As I said, ASU faculty is increasingly engaged in collaboration with Mexico. Some other universities are even more, like the University of Arizona. I will say that in the last few years it has remained unchanged, the amount, because the concerns for security in Mexico.
Francisco:
A lot of people is hesitant to initiate new things. I've seen people, for example, that has decided to decrease their activity in Mexico because security concerns, but even though I would say that has not been a decline. I'm more inclined to say that the amount of research across the border has remained the same. Has increased in some areas like climate change, for example. Energy. Those areas are areas where you see an increasing number of projects. Probably migration is an area where there is more research.

Ok. Yes, so basically after my PhD and post-doc, I began working in Brazil in 
2006 I guessed, I always focuses on the atmospheric sciences particularly 
atmosphere convection and thermodynamic. I also worked with gps monalogy. 
I was in a research institute in a university in Brazil in the Amazon, physically 
more than four years but I've been working with Brazilians since 2006. And 
2012 I took a faculty position in Mexico at the National Autonomous 
University continue along the same line of research. However, really 
developing a physical space in Northwest of Mexico and Southwest of the 
United States in what they called monsoon, the North America monsoon. And 
that have a been a big focus of my research in the last seven years even though I 
still continue to collaborating with people from Brazil and this summer we have 
a collaborative project in with Costa Rica and Columbia and that is major NAS 
funded scientific campaign, meteorology atmospheric science again. I am on 
sabbatical this year but I'm still participate in that project from UNAN. and I 
really have the strong international collaboration right now between my 
colleagues at the University of Arizona and colleagues in northwest Mexico and 
my institution in Mexico, it also spread out to other institutions in the US like 
Rutgers, University of Washington. I worked with people in Noah and Ncar 
(not sure what's that 5:15) those are atmosphere science organizations. So it's 
pretty board geographically but more recently have being here in Mexico and 
the US other than the recent project in Costa Rica. That kinda the general scope 
of the countries that I worked with. Also I have colleagues with connections in 
Europe too but I never physically worked with them.

Well, I don't know. one of the problem and this is true to Latin America in

students tell me it's very similar...very nationalistic kinda closed in that 
respect.

There are a lot. This probably takes a couple hours...I have...this is true in 
Brazil also not just Mexico but...one of the thing people tend to be very 
territorial. For example, people in Brazil and people in Mexico don't really 
share data, don't share ideas, there is very little collaborations in that respect. A 
lot of things are done behind closed door. They are not very opened with lights 
so you can see what decisions are made. Again this is also true in Brazil and it's 
not that it's true in the US. it's much more open in...also people in Mexico 
don't take very kindly to criticism which is I think of not ethic to academic you 
have to criticize you have to be willing to take criticism and that does not go 
over very well especially from American and in general. Those are very 
negative aspects from me that make research difficult in Latin America general 
and Mexico specifically.

I would say normally they expressed the idea...I don't want to say it's 
mantra...there is a lot of collaborations in different groups with US institutions 
but again like I said they are very closed off. They are not open to other people 
to get involved so you kind of have to look for like I said more personal 
relationships with people who are willing to collaborate in the US. Sometimes, 
that person has power in the institutional level that can help a lot. But if you 
don't have...I would call it political cloud or influence it's very difficult to get 
the institutional support.

individualistic, dog-eat-dog...so everyone would say they don't get into the

everybody, comparison would be hard to make. In Mexico, there is money and

Oh, I think that they could take place with many countries. What has happened is in my in my case, I have a knowledge of Mexico, I spent 45 years working in education in Mexico ok? And we have proposed that, and I agree with you, Arizona has several groups, like me, one is for different countries, Ireland, China, but one of the key points is you have to have somebody in the office who knows what is going on in that country. You see the important thing about the countries sake is that they limits the possibility for doing things. For my case, I happen to have the experience, I know who is who, where to be, where to not go, and that helps! And I see another group that who are staring in other countries or other areas, not necessarily they know the country and they assume that many things that are broken in the United States are going to be true in those countries, that is completely false. For right now, I am starting to work with more with Columbia, and I am going to work with Argentina and the reasons we havenít get to other countries in Latina America is because we donít have the time yet. You see we are already running, we start running so many small projects in Mexico are growing and but donít have time to go and interrupt and complicate because of security and things like that so you have to look to Columbia, Peru, Argentina, you can do a good relationship. And for right now is because we have the capability of doing that with Mexico, ok I donít know if I answered your question but the university has people related to other areas than you are.

Ok. The answer to your question is not a random system. Itís nothing that oh, if we are at the boarder we have more chances to collaborate, yeah? But in the end, it is the people that you put to do the job, the work. You but somebody in both sides who are collaborating, they are going to find a solution, but itís not like, you have to have a plan you have to put in the work, you can not just go like this and one day it becomes improved, no! Ok, so it is very important to put in the right people in these collaborations and people who seem really interested. I know that there are many professors who go by the smell of the funds, the money and that is ok, I understand, the US ID you send off the money to some countries and you are going to try and do one project in that country. But at the end you are going to have people who know the country, who understand the country, who help the university to integrate in their cultural in that country and visa versa. In that country you have to help, like you are doing, you are looking for persons who have experiences in Mexican education, in Mexico education here and thatís really the best way, where you find people who are affiliated with that country, or that person in the US, and that person is very valuable! Because he understands the systems. Unfortunately sometimes there are, the experience, the vison is not big enough and they reduce to the area of their research. I donít know if I explained this myself, but that is really, if you go to the boarder, if you go to of course if you go to the boarder the chances are higher. Those who are close to the boarder, are more interested but at the end it is who you put to do the relationship.

Sure! Because of all the, our challenges right now is to find money from organization in the US to fund these collaborative projects and that has very much effected the present policy. They change the students, they change the professors, of course they are going to be effected by these declarations, I donít know how to call it. When I was in Mexico, at the beginning I would say 80 percent of the students who went abroad I would say went to the United States. At the end, of 26 years only 25 percent or 30 percent of students who went abroad went to the United States, the rest went to the rest of the world. Why the rest went to the rest of the world, because everybody, the competition, it generally was to come and visit us, they wanted students come visit us. I will start with this example, it is very aggressive, it was to come and visit us, ok? They come from China, so pretty soon the students decided the wanted to go to other places apart from the country who was next to them and our territory was 35 percent. With these polices after 9/11 and all that is going on right now, that is certainly subjecting it from my point of view, you are going to affect the relationship with the collaborations the answer is yes, unfortunately. Ok?

Well, with the recommendation you have to talk, make the people aware why is important collaborations, not only from the academic standpoint of view. But the standpoint is systematic. This is an example, if you go right now in Mexico, if you come from the left, then you go to the far right well then it is time we are going to have the conflict. And guess what is going to happen when you have culture from two different countries which in the last two, three years have been collaborating with exchange with all of that ok? They are going to become enemies ? What do you think the Russians are going to do what the Chinese are going to do? They are going to have to think of strategy. So, without having a problem, without having countries to collaborate with, now we are maybe at a point where having two countries fighting each other.  And they say with that we are going to remove the water, and with that we are going to remove the trade, so if you remove things from the economic trade, well that is fine, maybe the United States will get some more water, I am not sure. Letís assume that the end you are going to have enemy and I donít think that is a very good idea in the long term

I am going to give another example now, NAFTA. I was in NAFTA, I participated where I was, I went to Canada, I went to Mexico, and United States. There was one initial thing that said the trade should no longer be brother services but also should be in human resources and Canada say I agree, and I am talking human resources at the professional level. Ok the United States is supposed to trade products and services ok? After 25 years what do we have? We trade goods and services but we donít have the exchange of persons and in the long term that is what made NAFTA week. You have to have exchange of persons who understand the culture and understand the position of the other and history of the other country and to be also to collaborate. So in the end it is the collaborations good or are they not good? Most of people that I have talked to, they are not aware of why it is important to collaborate. They just want to close their doors and build walls and then when they feel safe they thing nothing is going to happen.

o for the people, why we have to collaborate it is not any good without someones way of doing it, it is because we need each other in order to be able to improve the society. If you donít make it work than neither of the universities and neither of the government, and why is that important instead of having any connection. That for me is the first step, that will be my first recommendation. The person in Arizona is a world where is interested in improving the relationship with Mexico because Arizona is very important to have a collaboration from the standpoint of economic resources you see? Arizona is a very under the mellow state compared to California or Texas but at the end, that state is the best in the the trade that they can do with Mexico, you see congress is not aware of that and they just think they want to stop the difference because they are mad and they are all despiteful, then at the end I think the state is going to suffer if the state of Arizona so you have to make the word of why we have to collaborate instead of being quiet or trying to separate the two countries in a very not policy making way. You see the thing is, you have to develop, the central Americans are coming here, well that is because their economic stability is very low, and how central America comes to develop, we are always going to have insecurity, we are going to have depression, I donít care how many walls that you put. So, if you donít make aware the people, of all the communities, and I donít think, sometimes the audience is can sometimes be oppressive, but I donít feel oppressive,  so I understand the importance of collaborations. But if you put a traffic guy they are not going to understand, they are coming to waste money. They have to be interested in this collaboration and they have the vison of why this is important. In Mexico so we have the same problem, people of the university they are not aware of the importance of having these relationships with Mexico, it is the same problem is what I am trying to say, it is not just a United State problem. You see right now, north of the new wall that we are making why are, then we go backwards, then why do we have to send student to study at the united states instead of other countries, we can do that ourselves sure. And the long term I believe that it is not going to be from Mexico either, so awareness I would say is the more important uh issue.

There are two parts. One is technical like whenever I have some technique and someone else has another technique. We exchange and then collaborate by sharing the technique or doing different experiment to observe the same questions. The another is about idea, in which people are thinking about similar ideas. Without working on the same problem we start to collaborate to see if there are any common ground by the using the same idea. I think I have both collaborations.

So with MexicoÖin the last two years I have two. One is a funded grant through the UTC STEM and CONACE? It was basically a co, it was money. I want to learn about autism because I worked in the cerebellum and the cerebellum is greatly affected by the autism. I have some techniques, and then I tried to find someone in Mexico, the name of the person is Jose Mensor?  At the University of ??? in De Cruz (2:14). I found that he was working in the cerebellum, he worked with childrenÖthink that I need toÖso I gave him a callÖwe wrote the grant, sharing techniques that we donít know from each other and learned from each other. So we got it in 2017. What happening is that students from Mexico with those techniques come to my lab to performance experiments. There was idea sending people to Mexico but the logistic just didnít work out. Our sending samples from Mexico to the lapÖso we just decided to bring in the people, we gave them the money to basically bring people for one year. Thatís one. It is more complicated. I worked on aÖso I have an experiment side that work on the cerebellum, and I have a theoretical. Most of my works are theoretical. I worked with these strange equations that I called fractional equations and I applied them to the neuroscienceÖ. I was in a meeting at MexicoÖhe is researcher, and I was very into researching, so we got in contacted. In the last two years, he became a faculty, part of CONACE chair, he was a junior faculty for tenureÖ(unclear recording but something about collaborating and exchange students) through the PhD fellowship of CONACE, PhD students can spend a year outside, so I got a student who came and stayed for a year, a little bit more than a year. He just went back, and I got a new PhD student. He also came through the CONACE fellowship. They worked theory, electronic sequence that implement equations to understand how the brain functions.

The fractional theoretical mind have been driven by these very young students and there are very few people on the planet working on it. So I also have collaboration with people in Greece, in the United Arab Emirates, just because we have decline working on the field. There are very few people work on it in the US. So my other collaborator is in Canada. The field is very young because of that it is very disperse. People are working on the same topic but different questions. So I tried to bring them all together to see if we can collaborate around neuroscience using these tools and techniques. The other one is what I said before working on autism and from the funding.

Is it very common path or typical of people in your discipline to engage in international collaboration? 
Fidel
For international collaboration, itís more difficultÖI have a previous grant with Germany and it was the same way, with different mechanism between Germany and the US to fund specific grants or competition on neuroscienceÖI have other friends that we tried to collaborate together because we know each other for a long time but havenít work for whatever reason.

One is I am in San Antonio, and Mexico is very closed by. For whatever reason, we have very little collaboration with Mexico, my university. There are some motivations like itís easy to bring students and relatively cheap. There are good work been done there. Of course I grew up in Mexico, I got my undergraduate from UNAM. But I donít know anybody back. When I moved to do my PhD I did it on neuroscience, I decided that I want to meet new people, and I start to investing time. Iíll go talk to people eventually these things start appearing. At the third round of collaboration study emerging, in one of the opportunity I went I met friends and they put me in contact with the director of the complexity in UNAM. Then I decided to participate in the interdisciplinary meeting on neuroscience, and I have going for two years now thatís like a big organized by the ??? (9:35) research center in Mexico.

Itís difficult to say, but I can say that Mexican students are highly motivated. They may require more trainings but they are highly motivated. When they come, they really want to work so that is a different in the opportunity and everythingÖI think it will require a lot more money too because of the gigantic advantage all of these students have fellowships from the federal government in Mexico so they come to me and stay a year with me. Sometime I give them their stipend but sometimes is enough from the money they bring from Mexico. If I have to collaborate with someone in the US, I have to find the money to pay their tuition and stipend for the student which cost to $40,000 a year or more. That is a gigantic advantage.

Well, I speak Spanish so that is important, reduce some barriers. The facilities there, for example the one we worked cost a lot of money to get it started so it was a push from the UT system to do it. That is a great motivator. The other one has beenÖwe worked with other another theoretical person, we worked separately and talk and exchanged emails this kind of fellowship. For him becoming a professor and getting students we decided to do this and I have the money to complement so that facilitated. If the students have their own money is golden.

I thinkÖI have very little concerns right now. I thought I could do more of the experiments that we want to do but the thing is I donít know how to do them like we just send the stuff to Mexico and they told me itís not possible because the FedEx doesnít arrive on time with the sample, that change all the perceptions. This thing happened. I didnít have any serious problems so far.
Driven by us, the researchers.

How interested and/or supportive is your institution/department/program in pursuing
collaboration with faculty and institutions located in Mexico?
Fidel
Great question. I think I mentioned it but it is not really high in their priority. They donít see it. 
Ji Yeon
What about your department or program. 
Fidel
Itís the same. Itís not in their top 10. They see some advantages but they donít want to cultivate broadly. They appreciated that Iím doing it but they donít see it as a long term mechanism that everybody should participate, broader participation.

To what extent are students at your institution interested in pursuing projects or exchange programs opportunities with Mexican institutions?
Fidel
There is very little bit I think because of the lack of information, Iím saying that from the part of biology. We have a Mexico institute that have funding for people to go to Mexico thatís a different so I can see on the email. So I think there is more collaboration on that side, the humanity side and college of fine art. On the science, there is very littleÖwe have common meetings with Mexico, interact and something like that.

I think there is more interested in just getting their own grants. My colleagues haveÖa few have applied to me, the UT-CONACE system called Contact. There is interests.
I think they have this thing as I mentioned in the Humanity side, but I donít know if there is anything in science.

I think if there were, more exchange programs promoted. The science allows students to execute themselves in the laps and have some partners in Mexico that will receive them. Have something more organized other than like researchers started activities. they put the money for post-doc to move to Mexico here and there but I think it would be nice to have a more institutional organized approach to it. we can benefits from that a lot more.

On the Mexican side is the politics. They told me itís impossible to work. There is also cultural stuff. The Mexican students just donít want to come to the US, they want to go to Europe, and I think that is still true. so I think we have these barriers to find partner in Mexico that can be implemented an effective program.

On the Mexican side is the politics. They told me itís impossible to work. There is also cultural stuff. The Mexican students just donít want to come to the US, they want to go to Europe, and I think that is still true. so I think we have these barriers to find partner in Mexico that can be implemented an effective program.

I think sometimes itís easier to collaborate with Mexico because itís very near to collaborate, access to resourcesÖa lot of things that they have told me that sometimes students are very isolated. What they want is to establish some kind of pipe-lines for students to move around there is this kind of tendency to stay in the same place. That is a big motivation.

I thinkÖlike what I said in the beginning is closed and itís easy to bring people with all sort of talents. We trained and then can bring them for one or two years whatever time to work and itís good for them and for the training and they can fly to Mexico. Itís comfortable, so I think is another way is talent.

I thinkÖother countries the way you talk about things is more openÖitís more like a feeling. Like in Mexico, I feel like they are mistrust in the beginning I donít know why, a little bit of you have to show that youíre an okay person, itís might be a bit culture. I donít know. With Europe, Canada, and I have friends in Korea as well, itís way easierÖwell, in Korea I was told similar that there is mistrust of talking about their own works. They are afraid that they will be screwedÖbecause of the lack of resources, they donít want to share too much and they feared that they can lost the money, something like that. Thatís another barrier and it takes awhile.

with NSF, there is this program calls CRCNS, Collaborative Research Computational Neuroscience. In the US, itís between NSF and NIH? (28:18), later the European Union said well we want to collaborate so they put some money to fund the Americans and German side and then the French came, now the Spaniard, and now Korea also come to that program. Now that program is like a competition for computational neuroscience that promote collaboration across the planet. There are very few of those instances between NSF or NIH and CONACE. Thatís part of the institutional level. The only way to get money from NSF for Mexico is that if I have NSF money, my colleague in Mexico has CONACE money then we can request money for travel but not share project. Okay. I started working in Latin America because I was interested in, during the Clinton administration and Al Gore, in cooperating with Latin America. Especially in Brazil. So, they put money. My collaboration, well, my role as a collaborator was to find people in Brazil who could be collaborators. And that was my philosophy, 'cause typically, when you get a grant from NSF, or from any federal agency in the United States, it's your money and you hire people on your side. That case, my personal preference is to find partners the same level. Now it's a requirement in Brazil, but at the time I decided to start cooperating who could follow the research. Reasonable independent just of me. That they could own it too. That's how it started, and it worked. And now my colleagues in Brazil, they have their own project and similar to what we started.

Bolivia the same thing, and in Mexico, also started working with funding from USA ID to develop capacity ... technical capacity. And it was the same thing. Instead of just me going there and do research, it was me going there, but start working with people who had the capacity to own the project, own the research. So, I had it very productive for me. That's why I still do international research. But, I engage in research only if there is a contact part on the other side who they have interest and they can own it. And part of the ownership is that they can support their own, or they can find the support from their own country, just not depend from the funding from the United States.

Which is something that ... You have funding from NSF, that's only four years, or five years. It's short term, and there is no follow up. In that case, when I have funding from NASA, NSF, USA ID, that's terminal funding. But the way I was able to manage my personal interests and continue, is to find people who could follow-

I try to find people who have the scientific capacity and the institutional support to have a successful project.

That I have my own expertise, and my skills, and my own interests. If there is a problem that I know may have funding and that can be done in other countries, I start working with other people in the countries.

And when ... well, you know the situation in the United States. The funding has been declining and has been pretty bad in the last few years, in terms of working in environmental work. Not as big as it used to be.

But in the 90s, when Al Gore was Vice President, there was so much support for international work on environmental issues. Now there is not much. Now we are back into the old model of you find your funding and try to develop something in Latin America, and if you run out of funding, then that's it.

I follow two models. Back in the 90s when I started working in Bolivia and Brazil, it was through international meetings or meetings in those countries, and try to see who was doing something that could integrate with my interests. In Mexico, the model that has worked better, is they look for me.

And I have had three people doing sabbaticals from major universities. They come here, they spend a year, and we start working in ideas and various proposals that, eventually, when they go back to Mexico, they submit the proposals to the Mexican CONACYT, it's equivalent to NSF. But those ideas ... we develop those ideas when they're here. That's the best model I have found and I have received ... I concentrate mostly Latin American, not in many other countries, 'cause it's my preference.

Language is one of them, and also I love Latin America.
Roxana:
In the blood, right.
Dr. Alvarado:
Yeah. I try also not to disperse too much, 'cause otherwise I wouldn't be able to have something productive and finish. I just try to concentrate on one or two countries. And right now most of the work is happening in Mexico and Brazil.

I'm interested in working on conservation, protected areas. Management of foreign resources and fire, of course. Everything related to fire, that's my expertise. But they relate to ... and also native knowledge. Native ... indigenous knowledge. How ... And that's one of the things that I was talking to student previously, that was here before. You have tropical forests that have been growing like gardens, and you have places, you have cities, or pyramids around the cities that the dominant vegetation produce food, or fruit, or some human value. But only around the cities. Like, Chichen Itza or Bonampak. Away from those cities, those species decline. People call them the Mayan Gardens.

Of course that calls my attention because over the long term ... and the Mayans disappeared a thousand years ago. Yeah, around a thousand, a little over a thousand years ago. But we still see the forest being influenced by the footprint of a thousand years ago. So, I'm looking into future, by 2100, well we have to look into have a reference. And that's what I'm trying to do also in the United States with Native Americans. I work in reservations and I'm trying to understand how the forest looks today by integrating everything from the past. How far in the past? It's not just 100 years, maybe 1000 years, and since the tropics you can see the footprint of 1000 years ago, there's a historical footprint in all these forests, and even if they don't belong to reservations right now, their footprint is still there. And that's what I'm trying to learn about that so we can predict what's the future of those forests, how we can ensure they will be here for future generations. Anyway, yeah, that's kind of ...

One of the places I've been working in Mexico is the Monarch butterfly reserve. So we're doing a lot of things, or the government's are doing a lot of things to protect the reserve, the Monarch butterfly. And we're looking at what is reducing the forest or the habitat. Oh, deforestation, logging, and all that. But then you look at a hundred years ago, actually before 1970, there was no protection ... legal protection, but the forest was there. And you go back into hundreds of years, the butterflies were there, and they went there. The forest was there, but the people were taking care of those forests. Now we are blaming the local people, the indigenous people, like they are deforesting, they are moving the habitat and they are banishing the butterfly. How come they didn't before?

The forest was there, but the people were taking care of those forests. Now we are blaming the local people, the indigenous people, like they are deforesting, they are moving the habitat and they are banishing the butterfly. How come they didn't before?
So that's all some kind of examples. So that's why I'm interested in the ... not just the ecology of these things or the fire component, but also the integration of people.

Mexico ... Well Mexico and Latin America, in general, is the human population, the social processes are different than the United States.
Roxana:
Can you elaborate on that? How is that?
Dr. Alvarado:
You have more indigenous people still living ... Like the Mayans, for instance, the Mayans in Yucatan or Chiapas, they still follow their traditions on living out of the forests, collecting foods, and depending on the natural resources more than the US. Here people don't depend too much, even in the reservations, on their own resources. It's more cultural. But in Latin America there are still people doing slash and burn, in the traditional way. Or collecting, or hunting in the traditional ways. It's just the type of social processes that happen in those countries are a little more pure. I don't know if you can call it pure, but at least they are cleaner to see the footprint of the people on the natural resources.

Any experience working with people in communities around the United States?
Dr. Alvarado:
Yeah. Indian reservations.
Roxana:
In the reservations.
Dr. Alvarado:
Yeah. Native reservations. I have done some work in the Yakama Reservation, and also have graduate students who have worked there and the Colville Reservation. I have one Capstone student working on the Quinault Reservation on the Olympic Peninsula. I have, in the past, worked with the Navajo, the Apache Reservations, and one more in Nevada I don't remember. Oh, and also on in Montana. So, yeah, the Salish Kootenai. So, those are the groups I work with. I also work with federal agencies, but you never work with the same people. If you wait five years, there will be somebody else there, 'cause people tend to move. Native Americans, you will see the same people over and over.

Yeah. It's ... Some people think, or they have experience that it's difficult to work with Native Americans 'cause they have their own protocols. They are an independent nation. They are a different nation, so you have to treat them that way. It's not like the federal government with federal lands, that we own the land. All US citizens, permanent residents, own the land and you can go and ask for permission to do research there or just go and collect data. Reservations is an independent nation, so you have to treat it that way, and a lot of people don't do that. And a lot of scientists, they don't go into the reservations 'cause if they have their own protocols, and even if ... just because you are from one of the top universities in the world, doesn't mean they are going to open the doors for you. You have to treat them with respect and recognize that they have their own process and their own ... And every reservation is different.

There are no one standard. Federal lands, they have one standard. Forest Services, in National Parks, there is one national protocol how to do research in the lands. Reservations is one by one. And that's why it's complicated. You want to do research and accomplish something across multiple reservations, each one is different. And that's what takes time to accept and to work with them and try to finish something because they may have something different process.

What factors have presented as challenges to work with Mexico?
Dr. Alvarado:
Well one is the economic. Economic factors that they [crosstalk 00:18:17] ... Policies they change every six years, and the last ... People used to be more permanent in the government, and now every time they change the government, there's a change from the top all the way to the bottom. Which were there always. That's why I tend not to work with federal government in Mexico, or Bolivia, 'cause you deal with one person, the top level, or the media said it was so and so, or you go back in 40 years and you may not find the same person. You have to start all over. That's why I prefer to work with universities. 'Cause they are more dedicated to their own ... to their own ... develop their likelihood in one place. Does that answer your-

People who can respond, and they are people who can publish. That's one of my things they have to be able to complete. And, also, the other thing I work in Mexico, the type of my interest, personal interest, is if they do research that can translate to policy. And when you work with people who have already ... they have consolidated their role within that university or within the country, no matter who is in the departments or administrators, they have the institutional knowledge of what's going on, either in fires, or ecology, or management, and the next politician can come and ask them if they want to, instead of just working with politicians who may leave in six years or less.

So that's the main challenge. In Bolivia, it was pretty clear the first year I started working in Bolivia, or visiting Bolivia. Every four years there were new people and it was difficult to track 'cause eight years later you talk to people who they were trying to visit the places that you started working on eight years ago and no one know. "We don't know anything about that." "I was there." So those are the main challenges [crosstalk 00:21:09] people.

And now, in Mexico, the challenges are mostly related to violence in rural areas. That's why I kind of been slow in working in Mexico, because some of the places where I ... The type of work I do is forestry, and those happen in the mountains where things are not good in terms of safety.

In the past, I worked ... I have also worked in the mountains in Northern Mexico, and those are the most beautiful forests I've worked on there in the Durango, Chihuahua, Sinaloa, [inaudible 00:21:58] and those are the ... Now it's the Triangulo Dorado, that's where most of the ... That's where "El Chapo" was from. But in the 90s we could drive through those places, and it's a beautiful forest, and so remote. It was still in the pristine kind of condition, not affected by logging. But it was safe to go there in those years. Now it's very difficult to go to those places. There are some other places in Mexico that also have problems and I work in the mountains, and that's where people grow stuff. I try to avoid those places.

However, really developing a physical space in Northwest of Mexico and Southwest of the United States in what they called monsoon, the North America monsoon.

Ok. Yes, so basically after my PhD and post-doc, I began working in Brazil in 2006 I guessed, I always focuses on the atmospheric sciences particularly atmosphere convection and thermodynamic. I also worked with gps monalogy. I was in a research institute in a university in Brazil in the Amazon, physically more than four years but Iíve been working with Brazilians since 2006. And 2012 I took a faculty position in Mexico at the National Autonomous University continue along the same line of research. However, really developing a physical space in Northwest of Mexico and Southwest of the United States in what they called monsoon, the North America monsoon. And that have a been a big focus of my research in the last seven years even though I still continue to collaborating with people from Brazil and this summer we have a collaborative project in with Costa Rica and Columbia and that is major NAS funded scientific campaign, meteorology atmospheric science again. I am on sabbatical this year but Iím still participate in that project from UNAN. and I really have the strong international collaboration right now between my colleagues at the University of Arizona and colleagues in northwest Mexico and my institution in Mexico, it also spread out to other institutions in the US like Rutgers, University of Washington. I worked with people in Noah and Ncar (not sure whatís that 5:15) those are atmosphere science organizations. So itís pretty board geographically but more recently have being here in Mexico and the US other than the recent project in Costa Rica. That kinda the general scope of the countries that I worked with. Also I have colleagues with connections in Europe too but I never physically worked with them.

I did it backward. I startedÖas an American, I started in Latin American and came back to the US. Most people donít do that, thatís very unusual. Iíve never met anybody who have done it the way Iíve done. So that part is different. So yes, when I was in Brazil we worked with people from Europe, people from US and obviously my Brazilian colleagues and then in Mexico, Iíve been worked with colleagues here in the US. I like said I did it backward compared to most people I know.
Yeah. Yeah. I mean I did my Ph.D. and post-doc here in the US but my academic career really developed in Latin America.

Yeah. Well, yeah. For example, I studied one of the things that my colleagues studied, tropical meteorology so youíre sort out of luck in the US since we donít really have tropical climate regime. So you have to go basically south of 20 degree latitude whether itís Africa, Asia or Central Mexico, Central America and South America thatís where you have to study, you have no other option. Thatís very specific to what I do. There are others things that people are interested that are not confined to tropic or tropical countries where they can studied atmosphere science issues.

So itís almost like a personal than scientific that kind of relationship that still hold true in Brazil too. It started personal and then you expand into professional. So that is kind of how I got started and evolved over time then I applied to what I did in Brazil and then applied to Mexico. Does that make sense what Iím telling you?
Although, in Mexico they offered me a position right off the back but in the US they didnít have anything. So thatís another motivating factor.

I meanÖI think you have to have a personal relationship tooÖthe fact for exampleÖthe fact that I speak Spanish and Portuguese and things like that really help cuts across a lot of barriers and also because I know the history of Mexico, history of Brazil and Latin America so I think Iím a much deeper cultural understanding while here too in the USÖI would say the same thing that I grew up, live, and study in the US I could say with respect to my Mexican colleagues that there are  a lot of things that they donít understand so Iím kinda weird in that respect. Okay. Yeah, when I went to Brazil I haveÖit was a program it was a graduate program, master and Ph.D. It was nice at that time in Brazil so very different from the Brazil we are seeing now. There was a lot of massive investment in public education and particularly in the Amazon and money just very flowing in. I was inviting to be faculty direct thesis and teaching in addition to the research. It was principally research but I would teach one class a semester. So I have Brazilian students teaching and then I have my own students too. In Mexico it was the same situation although I have many more students and I only teach one class a year in my institution so it was much more focus on my research. I did teach in both places. I also taught short term courses, short courses. I also brought people from the US to teach short courses in my institution in Mexico. So I have done that quite a bit. Iím probably have done that more than anybody else in my center, also the people in the US my colleagues tend to be very willing and interested in going to Mexico so thatís a plus. I canít say that for everybody. I have asked other people and they donít work out well. So I donít push that, for the most part my colleague really to go. He is kind of a good guy and safe guy. So yeah, the teaching has been a major part. One of the part that I enjoyed the mostÖthere are conflicts joys and conflicts with students stuff like thatÖthatís universal. Thatís probably the part I like the most.

Okay. Youíll have to change the cultures from both sides to make it happens. In my personal case, Iím fine with what Iím able to do. Itís been hard, and I have put a lot of times on things that I shouldnít have to just to get it moving. Sometimes personal expensesÖin order words is not to deal with the bureaucracy of the Mexican institutions so a lot of time I just have to take money out of my pocket just to make it smooth and fast. It also true in Brazil too but in the US you donít necessary have that kind of problemÖso it doesnít really tell you anything if I just tell oh I need more financial support everybody does. For example, making the UNAM where I work less bureaucratic much less administrative oriented that would help facilitateÖthatís a cultural change. To give you an example my center, I think we are only 57 researchers  but we have like 10 people just to work in the finance department just to give you an idea. In the US it would be one for all 50 but in Mexico itís 10 but they created these jobs and they created this bureaucracy within jobs so thatís kind of controversy so you get a lot ofÖprocesses that should really take a day they will take like a week even though you have a lot of people working.

In the US side, again I think the structure is okay but the university I think in the last couple of decades has taken on the business model which the universities are not really design to be profit generating machines, there are investment in the future so I think that counting mentality in the fact that for example so many researchers in the US are soft money they have to make a little bit of work to pay their own salary basically given funding so I think thatís very counterproductive too for science because youíre not allow to have the time to sit and think about things youíre worry about your health care and salary. In Mexico, you donít have to worry about that, everything is pay for as a full-time researcher everything is covered in that respect. Iíve worked with a lot of people in the US that are soft money and they got three or four different projects going on and I donít know how they do it and then they have family and stuff like thatÖI donít understand how can they have enough time in the day to really carry out the research carefully, write the paper carefully and train the students carefully thatÖbut again thatís a culture part of the US system that kinda accepted now. Thatís normal. It wasnít like that in the US like 30 or 40 years ago.

Yes, exactly thatís problematic and thatís counterproductive. The slowness of the bureaucracy on the Mexican side and then the repetitive in rapaciousness I think will have to be done in the US side thatís counterproductive but again I think those are fundamental base line cultural things that are working, cultural in the academic sense.

I donít like this guy or I donít like that guy so there is of that and make it very difficult.

Yeah I think you really need to focus on the cultural and nature in the US institutions and the Mexican institutions at that structural level. The personal is always interesting but you can have personal war and family that exists but the bigger institutional prerogatives I see what is going to ultimately control or not and so they can do it kind of like a piece meal the way it has been done between individual institution and individual university and stuff like that but if there is not a larger scale kind ofÖfor example NSF? has the historically black college and university funding mechanism very specific to a specific group of people that have been discriminated againstÖyou could imagine something like Latin American research funding or even Mexico for that matter. You can imagine NSF for some other large or federal scale organizations opening up something like that. That would help, but how possible and realistic that is I donít know. The US, the continue kind of for lack of a better word corporatization of our university that depend on donors, depend on big business that kind of stuff is very detrimental. I think in general Mexico there is still socially support universities are free, students get scholarship. They donít graduate debts like the US, like most places in the world. So I think that culturally itís going to beÖfor me I can easily buy equipment in Mexico because itís not hard but to do that and justify in the US and then to collaborate with Mexico is very difficult.

The US is much richer but they donít have that kind of mechanism in placed. I say that to my colleagues in the US and I get like blank stares what are you talking about. I was like look in Mexico we can do that easily. For what they donít understand in the US is like look you get your Mexican funding how canít you pay my salary. You donít do that in Mexico you get pay your salary or your research by your institution you donít have to pay your salary or grants and thatís all the US people donít understand that in the Mexican side. So there are less likely to doÖthey said hey you want a cute experiment youíre going to install equipment here do this and that is neatÖletís look at the data but I canít spend anytime on it because I didnít get pay and thatís very detrimental. So I say well okay look I get pay you donít have to pay me anything you do your NSF grantÖIím working with a guy from Harvard right now, he doesnít pay me anything because I get paid. So I help him do his research I get on the paper, they are very interesting itís my area so Iím helping him with that but he doesnít has to pay me anything. Now if I get him on one of my scholarship, now he will be like how are you going to fund my students, how are you going to do, how are you going to do thatÖso I canít. Again thatís kind of cultural institutional.

They have been in my institution for 50 years and their advisors, slave-owners, have been there for 70 years. Iím not exaggerating you can find examples. Thatís a very common trait. I thought that in the 90s and 2000s, Mexico really push a lot of people to study outside even in the US where there is a period that they did that. In Brazil, they did it in the 2000s or late 2000s when I was there. And I thought that would help change the culture hopefully. But the problem is people are there for a long time and that kind of higher up level, hierarchy is not disappearing. They feel like look I give you this opportunity to study in the US you come back and you still belong to me. If you want to come back, you kind of have to follow that if not you will get shut out.

Definitely. Mexico is very rigid. Brazil is too. Like I said in Brazil in the late 2000s they have a lot of money that they threw at science and education with that you always get a little bit of flexibility but I guarantee you now with the constrictions going on that would be stifle very quickly. Mexico didnít have that so much inversion and investment in their educational system in the late 90s and 2000s the way Brazil did so a lot of people that left have come back and just basically you know some have move up to higher positions but they still have to answer to somebody who is higher up. There is not a lot of horizontal in that space, itís still pretty much like a pyramid.

Well, itÖbecause we are so closed physically, we share the border stuff like that is cheap and Mexico sieges the US as an easy way to get things done. So in that respect there is always a high ball on the collaborations. But I honestly I havenít see them really expanding I think with the recent trends between the two countries make it more difficult. I see this is as an anecdote, I see a lot of things come from Canada. All students said I want to go to Canada, they donít want to go to the US because of the climate. Iím worry about that. It hasnít affected me at all in any personal away. But I see in the Mexican side, I have a student right now for example, Iím like hey look you already live in the US you speak English, why donít you go back and I can set you up with very good people and you have a very good degree. But she doesnít want to. I have other students who basically telling me the same things. Again, this is anecdotal but I thinkÖagain if I were Mexican and listened to this coming of the US I wouldnít go either. This not helping. The cultural things we were taking about is much of a longer term but this kind of instantaneous and spikes and antagonism things like that doesnít help either.

Like I said for me personally it hasnít affect me at least or my wife either. In fact, I would say it is sometimeÖacademic colleagues tend to be more liberal more open-minded and I think they were embarrassed by the current situation in the US. In some respects, they are more willing to open their doors, I would hope. Maybe I fantasized in here. On the personal level, they said I donít really like this but the backlash to that or something that could impede that would be you know what Iím not sure the MexicansÖprobably hate us Iím not sure I can getÖI would like to help but I donít know if I really want to get involve in this since I donít want to feel any animosity. I can see people think like that also. My colleague is not the problem because they know me. They asked me how is this work how is that works how are things work in respect to the current political situation. I explained to them so they have no fear. But if you look at the larger general cultural sense I think academic will be much more willing to but that other side might be intimidating like well I donít know maybe because the US is so ugly these days so the people in Mexico might treat me poorly or something like that. I donít think it is true but I can see how people think that like.

Yeah, it can go either direction but I think that like I said in general the academic would tend to say you know what I would rather help Mexico given all the horrible things we hear coming out these days than completely abandoned. But when push comes to shove and things really getting done this and that I donít really know. Also the economic and environment and the way the university being funded and other stuff certainly doesnít help. They will have to open more very direct programs like we want to do in Latin American you know investment and interchange.
