That is called the UT Dallas Mexico Summer Research Program Ok? Again, the UT Dallas Mexico Summer Research Program. And in 2002 um we started collaboration with the University of NAME. We tracked, we assigned, an 8 week program for international students from the University of NAME to spend 8 weeks with us, to be able to, to be exposed to the labs to be exposed to the structure of research that we have here today, with this provision of UT Dallas. And the intention was mainly, itís to create a connection and to share the structure, the campus, with the students from the University of Conosjio And then with our success we are happy with really, the growth, emotionally the growth, professionally the growth, and physically. And they were becoming more and more duty from partnerships we accredited over time, year after year, summer after summer and basically created a duty that was from the partnership and some of them came back to UT Dallas but as grad students with the sponsorship Conosjio and UT Dallas. Meaning, the UT Dallas and NAME scholarship program. So, at some point we realized that this was becoming a mechanism and effective mechanism to recruit Mexican students that we basically on the successful hospitality of UT Dallas for those students to consider that it was making sense to come back to UT Dallas to pursue credit programs, many doctoral programs. The success of this exercise was due to the fact that other Mexican students were looking at us, and some of them were from partner institutions and they start asking, can we send our students as well to the summer program? And we were very pleased with that question from this institution and we start brining other Mexicans from  universities. So at some point we started doing this summer program for the university of NAME from South America from a research center which is in fact at  NAME, and so you know the whole cohort of these summer programs are becoming more inclusive in terms of graphic intellectual because some were coming from selective private institutions and others were coming from poorer institutions, some of them coming from the north, some of them coming from the center, that at some point the US Embassy Mexico, basically say we would like to replicate a program that has a national rep. And I was very pleased and very impressed you know? By that question kind of from the US Mexico Embassy directly and at this point we are offering the 5th best version of the US Mexico Summer Research program with a co-sponsorship of the US Mexico Embassy Mexico and the Association of Mexican Universities of Higher Education institutions came to us, UT Dallas and the US Mexico Embassy Mexico to sponsor additional students that we select in a very competitive way from more than 200 applicants every summer and now we just finished our webinar for candidates, for perspective candidates for the 2019 summer program and some of them are coming back to US pursue grad education with UT Dallas with the sponsorship with UT Dallas and Conosjio.

Canada, United States, Mexico some of us think that this includes the political climate, we start thinking more and more in an isolated way. In the US perspective, in the Mexican perspective, and I think we need to be more relaxed about that. So it terms with and in terms of being together. I donít really see any soon there wont be anything psychical about it really promote education or to understand education, and having more tools to be able to understand each other and to be more competitive so we can have fun and we can be- have a wonderful North America.

Absolutely. You know, you have this information exposed to you through other testimonies but its posted for you, that higher education in the US Mexico, is an amazing inventory of all the collaborations that are happening but at Conosejo its mainly a technology collaboration and is definitely the many other  thing they have on the agenda in terms of a corporation and research agenda in terms in terms of social science um and even arts uh, and others! And thatís not the case, thatís not the collaboration that we have here in  UT Dallas, but there is plenty of room to be even bigger and to expand that collaboration or lets say what has been the exercise of UT Dallas and US Mexico Science of Technology and others to share their experiences in social sciences and humanities in higher education related to Mexico. That may not be the case, that collaborating may disappoint those fields but they are their own institutions or even universities in strong social sciences that may be exposed or may be willing to identify those collaborations to US institutions.

Um so when I started in the acceptance of Mexico status in 2001, it was really big for me that to bring this project to the next level of its ability and to the next level of its implantation and then having more direct communication with Mexican higher education institutions to present the case and to show that UT Dallas was going to be a good destination for with Mexican  grad students. Thatís one thing they should working directly with Mexican higher education institutions selling a collective scholarship program. There is also locally working with a Mexican, the culturally general to present the case and for them to help me, to promote that partnership with Mexico to the administration of Mexico and they really help me to be promoting this program within their own network of the mexican movement and gradually to be more visible and exposed to the Mexican environment general sense of higher education. Also kept close very much with USA and with Meixco asking for guidance to see how I was able to be more direct to be promoting this destination and then also to have more elements to be competing in a more effective way to include mexican students. What I am saying is I was competing, and still competing because Mexicans they can go anywhere to study at grad institutions, to pursue graduate education programs because education in Mexico institutional guarantees, there is no cost at all for them to go to uh walla wall in Australia or to Cambridge in the United Kingdom etc. etc. because maybe the Mexican Center for Institutional Technology exchange full scholarship, full support for them to pursue um doctoral programs or masters programs. So at some point I was competing with other key nations in terms of higher education and may aspects of technology like Germany for instance or competing with England I was competing with Japan, with south korea, and may other great destinations that explicit in their portfolio of connections for their Mexico students to pursue graduate programs. And so the US embassy was very careful in this process and especially the division in cultural affairs that they have no commit work as well and it has been providing different circumstances that can pass to be able to elaborate and in this presence to reach with Mexican students

Um so I think I have seen, Im chewing different needs of admissions with Mexican institutions to find a way that I was putting this UT Dallas connected partnership to the next level of visibility ultimately to be able to put more and more students from Mexico to a point that I can tell you right now that the partnership between UT Dallas and has become a traditional operation and knowing that, it has been, we have had readily success  that the University Texas Center has especially became mobile at the system level, creating a specific office, the UT system office to be engaged, and to be um cooperating with the Mexican Institution of Science and Technology and extended this at UT Dallas to other campuses within the UT system. Um so I can say that we have become a point of reference in terms of the higher education connection between US and Mexico. That one is what is really my heart and I am very proud and I have been working in this structure day by day to create this structure gradually with a lot of patience and passions for what could be the outcomes of this partnership. Any questions about that?

And they have seen just an amazing win with the tuition Mexican themselves Conosjio how this program has been impacted. You can see that 20 years ago its not having to do what is right now in terms of rankings, in terms of international audience, in terms of these deliberations of, but what is really kind of a big big step is for (name of institution) to explore that in terms of the new station is with certain reservation because you guys didnít know the ABC or Mexican um, Mexican culture, or Mexican democracy or um the Mexican wage or for the business for a international perspective.

I think collaboration is one of those terms that abused a little bit I think obviously for me I think collaboration has to do with working together but I thinkÖI tend to set the bar a little higher in term of collaboration. For example, you could co-author something without collaboration you could split sections and everybody writes their own and then done so that is not how I tend to understand collaboration especially in the international context. I think ideally collaboration gives you the opportunity to learn from each other, work with each other and to achieve something that you wouldnít be able to achieve by splitting the work in half or work in multiple parts.

I think really make collaboration different isÖI think that research for itself tend to be much more open, ultimately when you write something on your own you have an audience when itís finished. For collaboration, you have an audience throughout the project which makes you much more reflected about the decision, about how you communicated with others and I think it makes more self-conscious process in my view thatís a significant improvement.

I had kind of some attempts. One recent one was about a year ago. It really was, there are more than that but one particular comes to mind and that itís very interesting because a colleague back in Mexico would seem interest particularly around issues of quality and ability in the context of high education but was kind of getting in the way right so I donít want to assign responsibility on one side or the other but in this particular case became real to me or evidence through the process of trying to communicate and get something on the ground was that my colleague didnít have the space, the work space to pursue research at the moment. There are tons of teaching, tons of demands in term of administration, also a significant responsibility of services, organizing conferences, an equivalent of NARA? (8:35) in Mexico. I donít want to push the issue because it also give me theÖI also have similar responsibilityÖit didnít seem to be the right time. I think because there are very few centers focus on high education in Mexico and itís difficult to find those connections and itís a very good examples of whatís get in the way and I think of course we are also very busy. I think also been base on a US university I have the space and to some extend the resources for research so I realize that I am in a very privilege position in ways that sometimes colleagues in other countries just donít have. They have the expectations and pressures but not always the support.

At the moment, I at various stages working with a few colleagues. I would say at various stages of collaboration the part here is that Iím doing some works with colleagues in China where I donít have the cultural background, the linguistic background and yet some relationship last that I traveled there a few times and worked with others around teaching and that has started to turn into a research collaboration. Again the part of it is that I donít have something like that or that level relationship building currently in Mexico where Iím from where I have the linguistic background I have all of that. I think part of that just kind of the alignment of interests. I think itís a little bit difficult to find colleagues in Mexico for me that are either at similar point in their career or has the space and resources to focusing on research. I think they pulled toward other responsibility whereas in certain countries their interest around research and publication and pressure to pursue that over all else and I would place China in that place. Itís very clear that there is noÖnothing doing research is not an option, they have to do it, very focus on that and rather ambitious I would say in their goals.

It was a new connection, it wasnít somebodyÖI think that is a disadvantage in my part right as I said I traveled to Mexico, I have the linguistic and cultural backgrounds but all of my graduate educations took place in the United States so unfortunately I donít feel very connected with those research network back in MexicoÖthere are limited resources in terms of conferences things like thatÖit was my own decision to prioritize some of the AERA, CIES PACH?? Those are three conferences that based in the U.S. every year or in Canada. So I donít have the space and resources to travel to Mexico for conferences, and I was making that decision because I been tenure and this is my tenure evaluation year has come to an endÖin term of messaging and my own interpretation was I need to prioritize the conferences and the journals that these people who are evaluating me are going to value or at least recognized. It was a strategic decision on my part but I think the consequence even though we donít intended was just been very disconnected with the time of research and researchers in Mexico and even in other parts include America.

It was more like a reflective process. I think it was at the point where I feel I could and start a new research project. Well, this is an opportunity to try new research and start to reach out, looking at researches and colleagues in Mexico so that is where these colleagues came across. I initiated the collaboration and it was very warm. I would say motivation was missing. We were connected, we had a few Skype conversations, and were okay letís work together and pursued some ideas, and there were a lot of time between conversations because I mentioned earlier there were other plans.

I would say time was a challenge and priority. I think if I have one more element, itís not different but I think itís a slightly different angle here but also motivation counts a big this is how to establish goal. So itís notÖyou know kind of the faculty ranks in Mexico difference, this is certainly a colleague who is far away in their career so the pressure to publish or to finish research projects wasnít as strong as my case so I think there is a difference, he is a very well established researcher in Mexico and I was in my early career at the time. I think strategically when I realized this was going to take a long time I also decided to rearrange my energy and time to get things done before it was time up for tenure. Itís notÖIím not saying Iím giving up but I think it was strategic retreat to kind of figure out what could be a better time to do it. So now when all of my materials are in and everything is looking favorable, then I think I can do. For example, this summer the World Congress of Comparative Education Society is taking place in Mexico, in Cancun so Iím going there, hoping to reconnect with some researchers in Mexico. Now I think itís about the next chapter and Iím no longer pressure of getting evaluated you knowÖ

Well, yes. It was kind of similar. Last time when I did an actual research project in Mexico was during my dissertation. I think there was still very similarÖat the time it was tenure pressure. It was more getting a faculty position. It was similar, I know it sound like I was blaming the system or making excuses for myself. But the message I was given as a doctoral student was the only thing that count for hiring committee is the number of publication that you have and the repetition of the venues that you are publishing. So again I think strategically at that time I made the decision if youíre trying to get collaboration back to the first question, the way I defined collaboration takes more efforts and significant amount of time. It looks like something that you can cultivate and something that you need to take care. I would say some of the demands of faculty life pull you away from that reality to cultivate this relationship.

I think both of them go very closed together. I tend to be driven collaborate with people that have similar questions that looks at similar topics I think that just reflected what Iím passionate about, the topic Iím interested in studying. I think this is the interesting thing I feel a stronger connection in affinity with people who study or research my topic. There are colleagues from my home country but they are studying different topics. I feel like I have much more commons with people from Norway or from China who can study the same things as I do right, we have very similar things and we all can collaborate some work so itís kind of exciting to have that connection and I havenít quite found colleagues in Mexico that have that closed affinity with the type of research or topics that I study. There is a good conversation like oh you study that and I study this. It makes an interesting conversation but itís not always like a natural connection in term of similar interests. So maybe that has been a struggle to pursuing more collaborations.

Yes. I think in some waysÖthe individual level for me is almost like we created a ball researchers in very closed to cosmopolitan. Itís almost like open more doors. Even international scholars in some waysÖthat align with my values to begin with but also it prefers activity that seem to be rewarded in the academy right. All the other things, in the U.S. sometimes rather often colleagues and others tend to see those of us are coming from the global south with deficit lenses that is also true. I think itís up to the individual to navigate how do you make sense of that, how do you negotiate that challenge because it might manifest itself in different ways. Sometime in passive ways right like sometime people mean things as complement rather than completely misguide or reveal a negative assumption about what we able or capable achieving as researchersÖI think and can only speak about the US deficit approach in educational context right you have to think about the lingualism, educational problems in K-12. If you speak two languages, thatís a problem but if you speak one then thatís fine. Thatís completely an absurd thought but that helps us understand schools in the US.

I think the reason is interest. I think people are legitimately curious about collaboration and some of us are aware colleagues certainly care deeply and they think itís important area of production given the histories, proximity and in some ways itís almost a reaction to their reactionary all of these we see in the US so people want to response to that and have all of these collaborations. At the same time, I think there is a significant amount of concerns and stigma about particular the sense of safety just traveling to Mexico you now all of those traveling and exercising cultural things. They tend to be a blanket statement right, there are a lot of nuance actually in term of understanding different regions. For people who donít really familiar with Mexico, itís almost impossible to make those differences so they just feel like everything is danger and they have to be cautious all time. Thatís one position and I understand right like for example in term of organizing staff travel or bringing students to study abroad, I feel responsible and concern about those things because you know sometimes Iím not extremely critical of that because I understand that there are certain risks, but those risks are also blow out of proportion.

I think people are legitimately curious about collaboration and some of us are aware colleagues certainly care deeply and they think itís important area of production given the histories, proximity and in some ways itís almost a reaction to their reactionary all of these we see in the US so people want to response to that and have all of these collaborations. I think there have to be an awareness that their willingness is there even though one...there is always challenge for collaboration right. I think the sooner we understand what those challenges are the more successful we can be. So I think the first thing is no one who pursue international collaboration should think itís going to be easy, itís never easy. I think once we get ourselves to get use to that thought we can actually be successful. I think that is the first step. Secondly, there have to be an authentic interest in understanding that itís a different academic culture right that in understanding the structural factors that get in the way. I was looking at a similar, a very small scale project when I was doctoral student with a faculty colleague and one of the first thing that came out as we were trying to explore the possibility and challenges of collaboration was our colleagues in Mexico were teaching four or five courses a semester, so well they want to do it. Itís a miracle that they are research active at all, but when you compared the work load, itís not that they work more it just mean that their priority is so focused on teaching that even if they were very motivated to pursue collaboration, this is a structural challenge. Some of them were telling us that when they have collaboration with colleagues outside of Mexico they were behind in deadline and they have to constantly explained to their colleagues that they couldnít finish the thing they have to do because of the teaching load they have so I guess if you are going to pursue, you need to understand the condition of colleagues are not going to be the same as yours. I think thatís an important approach

Another aspect is money. I think sometime theirÖa very good example is inequality that build in so you imagined that there is funding and the two institutions have agreed to fund the same amount. If a university in Mexico and a university in the US have agreed to fund the same amount, there already been inequality between the process because in particular the Mexican universities obtaining those funds is much more ??? (31:46) you just need to look at currency values, purchasing power that the same amount of money will have so I think this is a very good example where equity is not the same as equality. I think is always difficult to figure especially there is external funding and that external funding demands any kind of institutional cost share. It wasnít the institutions sharing the same amount. You just need to look at the budget right, you know look at the budget where there is $5,000. Itís going to be a pretty significant in one case but not always the same everywhere.

It has to start at the individual level. I have some resources but not too much constraints, I have to start at the individual level. I think it would be more like creating space for researchers from both countries without agenda without goals without expectation just to know each other and get to know the work they are doing. For me that will be the most likely way to achieve something. It can be mandated it can be speak from top down, but I think collaboration is a grassroots process and collaboration really start with two people deciding that they wanted to work together even before knowing what it is going to be.

I think international collaboration in generation is absolutely supported. There are a lot of interests. With Mexico itís not a high priority. Thatís what they care about, and if you can provide evidence that your project is going to do then that could become a priority, if not then itís not a priority. To be honest, there are few universities in Mexico, I think of two that would count in these institutions that ìmatter.î

Academic collaboration. Okay. So when I was in my career, I didn't have a well formed at a thought about what I do now. I didn't actually know what collaboration meant. I went through medical school and I wanted to do research and I had thought about it and I had projects where I needed some blood testing to be done in a scientific laboratory setting rather than the standard lab. And I have collaborator who turned out to be my [inaudible 00:00:54] Mexican colleague whether he'd be willing to run the specimen for me.
Dr. Boyer:
And he narrowed his eyes. He said, only if it's a true collaboration. And I saw all, I wanted his numbers and he said, if you're asking me to develop and validate and work on that day, you're asking me to be a part of your project and we're going to discuss what the focuses are and we're going to set the goal, then we're going to work together both house a valuable results. And I was a little bit taken back. I couldn't just that time understand what he meant. But I said yes Of course cause I did this test and then over the course of that through here, I learned that it really does mean that you have to go in at the culture, you have to respect each other's opinions, then you're willing to change course. Yes, it's benefit the project.

Where the most import thing that we did was ... with a little bit of funding that came actually from the Mexican government to [inaudible 00:02:12]. We decided to put on a workshop and the purpose of the workshop would be to bring together people from different fields. Oh, some how we can make it work together but didn't understand what that would be.
Dr. Boyer:
We had a five day[inaudible 00:02:31] where we started out by totally faculty and there were three major faculty and several additional faculty involved in the collaboration from several different countries. Well, we told the faculty that even if they just have the same title for their seminar presentation, which why would I know that you to know?
Dr. Boyer:
And we had maybe 15 people in the room that were handful of faculty and the rest of students and faculty may be presentations for each other but the students could listen. And each presentation had up to half an hour of the session afterwards when people got very excited, we've had a person who specialized in denim, was had one to develop that side bet we've had or the treated patients who were bitten by snakes. We had one who understood the physiology of the lymphatic system if they've never worked together before and each one gave a presentation.
Dr. Boyer:
And then we spent the rest of the week doing preliminary experiment when we would design an experiment each day and the students would rush off and set it up. When we had a small army of people correcting us preliminary data and by the end of the week we had to fully thought out plans for PhD this work. And in fact, two of the students that were in that room went on to get PhDs. It's very, very multidisciplinary fashion with collaborating supervisors in multiple institutions and doing that, having the students follow up on the shared goals of the professors works beautifully for everyone because we students could benefit from learning multiple things and from traveling and the faculty got to see things happen that could never have taken place and just one last.

Oh, I have a number. I have recently wrapped up and we're collaborating to write up a clinical trial. That is heart of a shared human medical kind to animal model collaboration, which is different from most other clinical trials. We study rare diseases, so it's made by Scorpion sting, spider bite, Ebola, things that are super rare. You can't just design a huge a placebo controlled double blind clinical trial across multiple sites. They just ... it doesn't work. So what we've had to do is negotiate with the FDA, what if we get the best information we can from an animal model and combine that with the best data we can squeeze from the occasional patients and we've just finished publishing the animal model, which is the one based on the PhD thesis which I told about and we've just simultaneously wrapped up the clinical trials. So instead of the traditional, do all the science first, then change here and do all the clinical work looking at time opinions because by collaborating we can help them at each other's work more.
Dr. Boyer:
We can get started with the clinical fiber 10 years earlier in a drug development cycle than you otherwise would say it's definitely tied in money and it's also a much more joyous process. Writing off a clinical trial right now that will be the parallel process to that laboratory. And then we have an additional collaborative project which started with the same group of people that had his new ones where we've discovered that because we were collaborating, we were attracting donated historical artifacts and people around North America really, we're excited to give us things that would otherwise go away. That represents a hundred years of our field. And the more that we accumulated and right now I've got a selection of 3000 files of add to that on the things like that. The more we realize we were sitting on the best source of studiable materials in the world on this topic and the Smithsonian got excited about it.
Dr. Boyer:
And so we're now looking for funding sources to enable collaboration that will be academic centers in the US and Mexico. It's Smithsonian, the FDA and the American Zoo and Aquarium Association. So it would be just really cool to get that. And when people see that you're having a fun collaboration with to meet cool people in travel, they want it to end, that it comes easier[inaudible 00:08:41] Fourth Project Rolling. It's hard to get funded for it. Nobody[inaudible 00:08:47] like, oh my gosh, it's a nightmare. But if you've got a handful of dedicated people who had money motivated so much as mission oriented [inaudible 00:08:59].

Multidisciplinary faculty at a university are what most people think of as collaborators. They have their own lab in their own side of campus and they attend a collaborative meeting with someone who has a different lab on the other side of the fence and you apply for grants, you get it to divide up the money, you go back to your lab and then you regroup and you present to the chest. That's multidisciplinary, transdisciplinary educators, and I'll get this number wrong so you have to look it up, but they represent something like 2% of the population of professors have the weird maverick behavior pattern that goes with transdisciplinary work. And according to at least one study that I heard presenting, if you have one transdisciplinary minimum of one transdisciplinary, type a few number on a project, it's more likely to have a longterm much. And the transdisciplinary person is like, oh. In the olden times, we've had a specialty in science called the naturalist.
Dr. Boyer:
But a transdisciplinary person doesn't mind being ignorant and likes to cross over into other fields and will actually visit the other lab and work there humbly not working ... not worry in the ... it's owned by someone. But it's where the science could get done. Or we'll go out in the field where we'll travel someplace else. We'll try out another language for conference in order to meet the other people even though they sound stupid in their second language or whatever. So a transdisciplinary person is motivated by desperately wanting to work in the field and do things even if it means not being normal. The problem with transdisciplinary workers will make studies feminist, I wish I could quote it for you in this thing that I've heard is they don't get promoted. They end up paying less than other university faculty because no department had seeds benefit from over around too much.
Dr. Boyer:
And they don't fit the normal criteria. So they're less likely to get raises. They're less likely to be promoted to the next level. But if you can get one on your team, it's more likely that a broad cross sectional study will work. And my team, I am transdisciplinary and clearly that stage person. So is my main Mexican collaborate. And by having two people, one on each side of the border who desperately need each other, I could not have done anything in my career without this Mexican collaborated. And likewise he would've been ... it would've been a successful scientist, but he would've been just sort of stuck in Mexico without the US clinical celebrity. When you have a couple of crazy motivated people who are willing to take risks, willing to separate along between grants and do things desperately for a while you can keep things going.

You also have to contextualize this, because I am telling you about my experience from 1998 to 2014, four year ago, where we were practically pioneers doing this. But, after that, I have seen growing interest in studying abroad among american universities. In mexican universities, they are also more open about mobilidad among students, so, there was a sudden interest on international collaboration, among students in particular. Not much scholars, because scholars have also want this, but they are so busy teaching and working, and doing all of that.

So for an american university, and I think for mexican university also, the student international exposure is the most powerful, because this is the core of institution.  So I have seen significant interest grow in both sides, but in particularly in the United States. And that make a big difference. 
Right now, for instance, I am going to start teaching at a SDSU class in University Baja California in Mexico, crossing the border every Wednesday. We will cross the border once a week. 
All my student from the United States are going to sit down in classrooms at the University of Baja California, and I will be teaching over there to both my SDSU students and mexican students in the same classroom. 
So, this is something that starts, oh my god, maybe  eight years ago. And the professors, of course, are also going to be crossing the border. This time I am doing it, I am not the only one doing it. There are other professors. This is part of the study abroad course requirements.

The american majors, as part of their, lets say,  the marketing, or why not, the administrative part of their marketing...  the real genuine interest of american scholars, who are latin scholars or experts of certain kind of topics globalization, for instance, or trade, or human traffic, or something that has to do with international dimensionÖ they created additional requirement for the majors. And one of those was a kind of international exposure. SDSU, I think it was in 1999 or 2000, had a provost who herself had studied abroad exposure when she was doing her PhD.  so being the provost of SDSU, so close to the border, we are less than 20 miles away from the border, 20 miles from the border, she was very open to require from major, that for instance, in international studies, that in Latin American studies, chicano studies, some study abroad program requirements. 
And they opened many study abroad programs. Chile for instance, is one of those countries, France, Checoslovaquia, but not all students can travel, because they have family obligations, work obligations. So that... for instance, the class I am going to be teaching is for those students who need to meet[class international exposure] requirements, who cannot travel for six months overseas. 
And for the students who are interested in studying with students from another country.

Academic collaboration to me means, respectfully win-win achievements. Yeah. I think when you said collaborate it means working together and it has to be in equal terms and benefits and as well sharing the work with the others. It's not like a paternalistic way but with respect, both put in the same and have a common goal.
I do have had solo projects and as you said, it is more looking from my own interests of research and my own research activities.

The collaborative projects I have been more in the administrative part not conducting research myself but putting teams of researchers to produce issues that are part of my mission of my program. Let me give you a concrete example. The migration and health research program, PINSA, for it's Spanish acronym. Instead of me doing a research on reproductive health and it's an area that I'm really interested on, of immigrants both in the US as a country of destination as well as the impact it has in Mexico country of origin, I call the experts of two major institutions, seek the funds for them instead of just for me, give them the funds and let them do the project.

Because I cannot be as we said in Spanish, [foreign language 00:04:54] and yeah, and the approaches that we need to understand the health of immigrants which, is what I do, [inaudible 00:05:07] barriers, disciplines and perspective. From validative to quantitative, from mental health to reproductive or work related injuries or environmental assets or mental health or addictions whatever it is.

So I convene the experts. What I do is I seek the funds for them and then we monitor their progress, I have a team and then we disseminate the resources through publications both, once we asked them in order to give them the grants that at the end of the project they have to produce an article to be submitted to appear in International Journal, but we also publish through our own mechanisms. Our reports that have a large division, their results.

So basically, is to ... When I started this, it's a negotiation with your ego. It's not you as a big capital "I" anymore, but it's a "We." And you get diffused in the "We," but the field gets enriched.
I have to give up a lot of my kind of, rigorosity's and accept that there are other perspectives and what I don't give up is the binational perspective in the study of migration because

I have to give up a lot of my kind of, rigorosity's and accept that there are other perspectives and what I don't give up is the binational perspective in the study of migration because I think in order for you to really understand the phenomena you have to understand that migration has an origin and a destination, so, it affects both. I'm not just gonna study here, the people what going on when they're in the US but it has a ripple effect in their communities back home, let's look out an example, mental health or addictions or communicable diseases. Yeah.

So what inspired me was the reality of the immigrants here. I came to this country in a very privileged situation, because I cam to do a post doctoral degree, meaning I got a visa to came and I got a grant to do a post doc. While I was doing the post doc that was in my own research area, reproductive health among farm workers and it was AIDS big apademia. I realized that it was a problem but it was not the main problem. It was like to see the leaf in another forest of another tree. And then I immediately was shocked about the conditions the immigrants was living in this country. Deeply shocked. The lack of humanity, the lack of dignity. The terrible living conditions. I think there are three major issues. And I will divide in structure, process and results. Structure, you have to have strong institutions behind, I would not advise anyone to do a one-on-one on human beings. Not because I don't believe on that but I think, the institutions kind of, how do you say this? In espagnole, you say [foreign language 00:29:41]. It means, give more protection.
So structure is very important. And structure it's bread by the institutions either academic or government. Number two ...

Once you start that sign form of the MOU's, sign formally spell it out, what do you want? That's part of the structure it means we're not going to, said, oh, we're gonna sponsor research but finally it's there to sponsor theater. No. If you're gonna say one thing you have to spell it, commit, with goals with objectives, with timelines, and number two, I'm going to do the other thing in the process, and it's very important to follow up and to monitor progress. You don't want to have surprises in the middle in the middle or at the end of the project. You have to schedule conference calls, or organize meetings through out the year so you can see how the order is moving forward.

There is one faith that has been key in this for me, trust but verify. Trust but verify. You trust but you verify and you verify by monitoring. Monitoring progress. And don't ... And the interaction, the periodical interaction which is part of the process really is fundamental. Number three in this process part, respect differences. Cultural differences, linguistically differences, acknowledge them, don't deny it but work on them once they're making some noise. I told you for instance, time perception or, oh, I was expecting you to ... No, let's set up the goals for this month in the monitoring part and let's see if it is for this month, it's for this month.

eah and once we come to the third thing, the results, be sure of two things, one to acknowledge the other and to acknowledge the other not in a paternalistic way, but in an equal, in a peer way. It's a collaboration, we both are working. There is no better one than the other because there are some resentments and then the realistic visions, sometimes is, oh, I wanna teach the little Mexican's. No, Mexicans also have some things to teach you, no? And all the gringo's don't understand, no? It's not that the gringo's don't understand, they have other perspectives.

Sometimes researchers become mercenaries. They go where the money is not where the research needs our ... Now China, what the gates is funding in Africa is very attractive. There is not much money now to research in Mexico unfortunately. So it's tougher to bring researchers interested where the money is not over there, it's not the low hanging fruit. It is not even though we are neighbors with Latin America. So, it is not ... Sometimes it's like ... And I don't want you to misunderstand this. I appreciate a lot of researchers who are genuinely are doing research in other geographic areas or in certain topics but what I've seen though out the years, their agendas, the research agendas, sometimes are dictated by the funding topics or interests or foundations. Let's put the AIDS Foundation as an example, they're interested in AIDS, so you see a lot of researchers who were doing environmental issues, now, they are doing AIDS research. Why? Because the money's there.

Roxanna, you should know that in order for things to happen you need leadership and people who's committed for things to happen. To follow up, follow up, follow up. I will not be tired to say that. I think it can mean quite a few things and part of me thinks about the theory of academic collaboration, but then I also think about my own experience with academic collaboration, right, its one of those concepts that is kind of fuzzy you know, like we mean pear to pear collaboration, collaborating with someone else on my institution, collaborating with someone on my institution but not in my program, but then I also think that we use a very restrictive definition of collaboration, usually in the literature is meant to sound like is partnerships, its usually partnerships with industry, but the reality is you know, especially for those of us in the social sciences is far more common for us to establish partnerships with communities, with NGOs, with governments, and think that’s just like any shared labor with a common purpose and that can take so many different forms. Definitely know creating academic knowledge can also be about how can we bring something to our community, how can we give something back, so I can have that kind of broad idea of what collaboration means.

For example, people that I have worked with in the past and that we are working on projects together, publications together, that kind of thing. Oddly enough, one of my most recent collaborators has been my sister who is a professor in Mexico and she is in a completely different field, she is in environmental sciences, but we did know that we had kind of shared experiences when I was teaching in Mexico, about infringement on caution.

I can make freedom and how that is layout in Mexico, so we wrote an article last year about what that looks like you know and that is something that I never expected because we don’t work on the same things, but that was really exciting to me, other people that are collaborating with me right now are my former advisers from my doctorate, from masters and this is in terms of research, there is also things I’m collaborating in terms of service. For example, the service that I do for CIHE and I know that it is not usually considered within the narrow definition of collaboration but I just cannot separate it, is work that you do together, work that starts as a service and may leave down the road to work that you do as a researchers, co-authors. So for me is very hard to make that clear cut division between what is service to the profession, service to the community, or when it becomes a more research or other kind of collaboration if that makes sense.
and my area tends to be kind of marginal to what a lot of people are doing in higher education, so in that sense that requires more being on my own.

But working as a collaboration you know, you have to take other people’s time lines and life circumstances, and all these things to take into consideration, but even though it can be challenging, I do think it really enriches the project, because you have more people looking at the same data or thinking differently about things that haven’t occurred to you, and again extending that notion of collaboration I see the work that I do with my doctoral students as a collaboration with early career scholars even though that might been seen as well you are training students, well no, I am collaborating with experts in the field, they have extensive experience in students affairs and in things that I don’t have that you know face to face experience, but they do, and so when we are working on a research they come with ideas that I have never expected to think about that so we can follow those so I found that very rewarding, so there is an aspect of collaborative research that is more rewarding than individual research.

But then there are activities that you do with peers, that I wouldn’t necessarily consider collaboration more than general support, for example, hey I have this manuscript would you mind reading it? You know, are you helping me, yes but is that a collaboration? I would say no, because I see a true collaboration involving a sustained effort over time with a group of people or one or two more individuals. So does that?

I did my undergrad in Mexico, and then I did my masters in Canada and then my PhD in the U.S. and also in transitioning from my bachelors to grad school, I switched fields. We don’t really have higher education as a field at the undergraduate level, so I think that is fairly common and so the field that I was in before, was more related to EFL, translation and literature the overlap of those three areas, so for the longest time I was very much in touch with the faculty there, because I had been an adjunct in that same program and so it transpired when I went to do my PhD that this program that was running at the time in Mexico, PROMED Programa del Mejoramiento del Profesorado.

Some of my professors of the undergrad were doing PhDs at The University of Arizona  as well while I was there, but we were on different fields, so I was in higher education, and they were on I can’t remember ah second language adquisition, so you know we woud get together just to talk about different things, that were happening in the program so I was very much still involed in the community of the program, but not neccesarily in a collaboration with them. I did participated on some conferences that they organized annually, and you know just to keep that involvement in the community. Working together in a project, we didn’t, and then overtime you know, I think is just that specialization.

I was in higher education working on very different things that they were working on and so it was hard to find a common ground as to what we were working on, even though because they working in higher education there are project that we can develop but something I did noticed is that a degree incompatibility in the sense of the teaching load they had working in Mexico and just the expectation of service and everything you know they came back, part of PROMED was the idea that we need to socialize faculty in more research type roles and learning to do research and I think that was a great idea.

I was in higher education working on very different things that they were working on and so it was hard to find a common ground as to what we were working on, even though because they working in higher education there are project that we can develop but something I did noticed is that a degree incompatibility in the sense of the teaching load they had working in Mexico and just the expectation of service and everything you know they came back, part of PROMED was the idea that we need to socialize faculty in more research type roles and learning to do research and I think that was a great idea. But what they didn’t account was when they go back we need to give them release time from teaching so they can do research, you know so they got the training in research but then they go back to teaching a full course load which is just insane if you want to have a research productivity on a long going basis, which is very very demanding. And that side of the coin made me be on the tenure track. So if there has been an opportunity to have a more you know an actual collaborative project, it would probably had fallen on me and I’m not there right now and like I don’t have the resources or the time available to put into a project that is much easier for me to put it here you know. So I think it was kind of like a perfect storm of things, we might be able to collaborate in the future but because those two things were happening it just made it very difficult. I’m in touch with other faculty in Mexico that I met once I was in grad school, but we haven’t really worked on anything together.

Yeah, that’s a very good question because I CIHE used to provide that space you know and they were very very strong. It was a meeting space where you would develop these projects and ideas you know, and you had a chance to talk to people and what are you working on, and what are you interested in and let’s work together that kind of thing. So in the time that I been in the field of higher education, I saw that happening. And then since 2016, we have seen that dramatic drop in the participation of Mexican faculty coming to the US and I completely understand and respect it. So there is a political element to it as well, you know that is very uncomfortable. It’s just very very uncomfortable in because in some way I feel that I have to justify why I am still here when the political climate is so anti-immigrant, so anti-mexican in particular, and at the same time respecting that their decision well, I cannot be part of this community right now because I can’t go against my conscious and train this country that is been so hostile and xenophobic and all kind of madness, so that complicates things for sure.

Yeah, scholars who are working in Mexico and are based in Mexico, yeah, for sure, again I think for example in my particular field of international higher education I know CIES, part of what they did it was really amazing because they hold the conference in Mexico City last year, you know and so that willingness of going beyond what does it mean to get together, where do we do it, the only time that ASH did it was going to Canada. But then we see a difference in the field of study right? CIES is more open to international and comparative education, is not just higher education you know but there is that willingness to consider there are other systems in the world, and it doesn’t have to be about the US and I always found ASH  to be very US centered, so that willingness is not necessary there, in the same level that might it  be at a conference that has just a bordered a natural international fit, and think that is just you know, I think is many things, but one of them is just short sidedness, that you know we need to talk to each other.

I think there is an opportunity there to do a lot more, but at least in my personal case, I mentioned the structural barriers, both on the parts of people that I have known as collaborators in the past, the faculty that are in Mexico and my current very real constrain of being in the tenure track and needing to crank out stuff, when that type of collaboration might need longer to come to fruition and that is just the way collaborations are, you know is a reality of them. Is not not anything wrong with that is just the structural constrain of needing to polish-polish-polish runs contrary to that, runs contrary to the development of long terms sustainable, on-going, collaborations with people who are not basically close to you, and who might have very different needs and priorities based on what higher education looks like for them, and for them is incredible teaching book.

know that system very well because, I studied in it, I’ve studied it, but that doesn’t necessarily means that that experience is the same as how higher education plays in Yucatan or in Mexico City, so that attention to context matters a lot. So, somehow of clearing house or faculty coming together it would be very useful; otherwise, it’s pretty much you as an individual reaching out to people and seeing if they have the time to talk to you and some do, and in that sense you know, that’s also again a researcher to make those connections,

I think, you know, I always wonder if CONACYT could do something about it, in the sense of providing funds for simply for networking, for coming to gathering, thinking about projects together, and that doesn’t mean necessarily that we have to provide all the funds for everyone to come for example to Mexico, it may be simply setting up the resources for having zoom available for Mexican scholars or saying you know we have this seed money for projects collaborating with other Mexicans in the US, Mexicans in Canada, Mexicans in wherever and, because once you graduate from your doctorate and then you are done with your CONACYT and what sponsors students through them, it is like well now you are on your own, you finished your commitment to us, but there isn’t an structure way in which we can continue to have these conversations, like I for example don’t know many other people in Mexico, because simply as I said, I switched fields, and then most of my work has been, even though I had continue to work on topics in Mexico, they tend to be topics on the context that I’m familiar with which was Chiguagua, you know that is the other thing, we don’t often think about how context matter. I know that system very well because, I studied in it, I’ve studied it, but that doesn’t necessarily means that that experience is the same as how higher education plays in Yucatan or in Mexico City, so that attention to context matters a lot. So, somehow of clearing house or faculty coming together it would be very useful; otherwise, it’s pretty much you as an individual reaching out to people and seeing if they have the time to talk to you and some do, and in that sense you know, that’s also again a researcher to make those connections, is just that all of these takes time, and that’s the, it’s not even about money, I don’t think, you can make always things work, but it’s the time constrain on both sides I think a real barrier and it also matters that you know like I mentioned, the faculty that I have are teaching a lot, that is not necessarily the case for people who are in more elite positions in Mexican universities, like those who belong to SNIT (Sistema Nacional de Investigadores) who may have more course releases, you know, they don’t need to be teaching as much, maybe they are part of research centers, that’s what they do, so in that sense collaboration ends up having this bias, in that you its far easier to establish collaborations with people who are in those centers of power, rather than the research that I am interested in, which has to do with where I come from because that’s what matters to me, you know and this was a regional institution, not prestigious, but those are the topics that interest me, what is happening at that institution, and I know that can be considered as kind of short-sided but I think we need more research that speaks to local context at the same time, not just aggregate data at the national level. It doesn’t tell you the whole story.

I would say, US and Europe and that has a lot to do with me having participated in an international collaborative project when I was a doctoral student, and so that is what I mean with the networking event that the European Science Foundation put a lot of money into that, just bringing people together to work on a project and that has really payed off. Actually, I don’t know how much money that was, but we had the opportunity to get to work together, well I did, in Finland, in the UK, in Germany, and so those are people that I’m still pretty much in contact with and continue to work with in different fashions, because we had the time and the space to establish partly a more human connection, you know get to know each other and know how we work, which also matters you know. You can be interested in the same topic but have completely different working styles, and that can do collaboration because that requires such intense contact with each other, and so from that project you know I gained good friends, I gained very good collaborators, and this didn’t happen with everyone in that team, but it did happen with a few and so with them I continue to nurture those collaborations because we already have that history.

It was a lot of fun, I learned tons, but a lot of it was trial an error, a lot of it had to do with not having a recognition of life stages, in the life of the academic, and we wrote about this. And so they designed with their vision in mind and so they needed people to conduct the work, and there is where the research associates came in, and post docs and staff, and we had those in all the teams, and what we ended up seeing is that because the leaders of the team did not have this pressing concern or this pressing need for outputs, for deliverables.

I was on the point where I needed to go on the job market, and you need publications right, the people who were post docs, who were in Europe at the time, where looking for academic positions. And what you need? You need publications now, not next year, not in two years you know, and so not having that clear path of what happened when, and how we do account for the fact that not everyone is a full professor, and people have very different needs at different stages of their academic lives. So, I think that is a huge problem and a real threat to large initiatives.

You can hop on a train go to another country do some interviews and then comeback in the evening or the day after. They don’t have that kind of detail on their website and the faculty, if we asked for their CV ahead of time they would have felt that was intrusive. There were a couple of things, I went to ASH one year and then to CIHE, and I was presenting something and at the end of my presentation this person came to me, and said, I really appreciate your project, and I saw his name tag, and I said that’s you, I just read your paper and I love it, so he ended up becoming a really good friend and collaborator, and then he said we are having a round table tomorrow about this project that we are trying to get off the ground, and I was the only person that went to the round table and it sounded really interesting, and then I got back to Arizona and a few weeks later, I was a GA, and they said you know, this project is coming up, would you be interested if it actually works out, and I said yeah of course, it turned out to be, like I said, they come in clusters of pre-existing networks, and they take new forms, they add more people, you have to have a way in through an advisor, a mentor that is interested in you and says hey, this opportunity came up, or there is this conference application, so having good mentors makes a big difference when you are a student and are just trying to get into these kinds of things. So there were two graduate assistants hired for that project and the other graduate assistant also became a good friend and we collaborated on those stuff again. It takes time and trust to develop that knowledge of how you work together, that I wouldn’t have had a chance to work with her if it hadn’t been for this project. So that’s why I became involved.

But in the sense of how do I get to hear other points of view is usually by going to conferences.

We used to have to drive to El Paso to go to Utech University of Texas en el Paso to get journals there and to have to literature that was from Mexico but that wasn’t collected at my local university. So, I think there’s been a, so I think Promed has been very visionary but at the same time I think it has been very short-sided in the expectation that oh you just need to know how to do research and everything else would take care of itself and it’s not true you know. There are still tremendous barriers once you go back, as an academic and you don’t have access to information.

You know what, I couldn't tell you that is a method. There is a procedure that used to follow. Because we are all the time solving problems that were not ... that we didn't expect, yeah?

Hector:
But we have to improvise a lot. A lot of research has to do improvisation because we are discovering things we didn't know that happened. For example, why we decided that we needed psychologists in our group of research? Because we started to see problems of trauma, anxiety, a lot of depression, and a lot of behavioral issues that relatives of victims were enduring. And if we had a goal to empower them in order for them to be activists and be people who work in the solution of their problem by themselves, we needed first of all to work with their psychological problem.
Hector:
So we invited a group of psychologists to be collaborators in this. We didn't have this before we met the people. We didn't think it was important to have psychologists in our group. But when we saw the problem, we had to look for the solutions and to look for those specialists that can help us.

Well, if we are really serious in looking for collaborations with Mexico, we have to start just with locating the most difficult issues there. Then locating those specialists that are working in those problems. Then looking for those institutions who have all kinds of resources. It's not only funds, but also people, labs, et cetera, that can be useful for our project. It's a question of doing several kind of agreements between not only colleagues, but institutions, organizations, communities, et cetera.

There is a political world there. We have to negotiate. We have to dialogue to come to some common interest, et cetera. That takes time. It takes a lot of meetings. It takes a lot of money. Right, so I have a number of projects on going where I write papers together with people in another country. So I guess I would count…when I was a grad student I went to Mexico and lived for a year while I was doing my dissertation which was using confidential data on Mexican manufactures. While I was there I met David Caplin??(2:20) who is an American but he was a faculty in UNAM in Mexico City. And he was using data also on Mexican firms from the social security. So I thought it would be cool to merge the data set that we were using so I went to meet with him while I was in Mexico City, and that is where that collaboration started.
And then with Moris we continue working with a graduate student from Colombia, David Caplin steps off, and with the graduate student we also have another paper that try to get publish soon.

There is one thing I should tell you about so the Mexican, the confidential Mexican plan data, when I first started use it I went to ??? (12:48). I could use it there in their offices, subsequently, David established a data laboratory they called it I forgot the official name. so that now is sort of formalize, you go there they have process and rules so you can’t bring any pen or papers or anything into the room and you could use the data. The process of using that laboratory though has been…was a little bit complicated. They won’t have… researchers have to have institutions that they’re working with or employed by to have an agreement to allow other researchers to use that laboratory. Columbia doesn’t have such agreement, so when I was started they prohibited me from using the laboratory. It turned out because I was doing consultant work for the World Bank at the time with ??? (14:05) the project The World Bank has an agreement so that facilitated me to using the laboratory…if I didn’t have this relationship with the World Bank then it would be much more difficult. Now I am in the process of getting Columbia and ? (14:23) to sign an agreement to allow researchers from Columbia to use laboratory but it has been a long and very slow process. It seems to move forward but the ? (14:35) in charge person is actually quite open to establish these collaborations. And Columbia is dragging its feet but it’s moving forward. It has been many years process to have them to sign this agreement.

So the reason we want to do this is because it gets us to move in a regime way neither going super fast but neither are you going super slow, and regardless you are able to maintain really nice moving speeds in the ocean. One thing that I have found challenging is, so that platform is great, and after that we have been able to jumpstart this project. So when I started, we censored my team along with my students and at one point I said ok we need someone that is an expert in kinematic modeling  because it is going to be too hard to try to do everything by ourselves, so I donít know, I have been in this job for like two years, two and a half, and it is really hard to collaborate with people, I think everyone initially is pretty open to it, and excited about it, but when it actually comes down to ok letís figure out how to translate this work, in particular when you are not in the same location, it is pretty challenging because most peopleís priorities are not aligned so someone might have a timeline of years, where a few might have a timeline of months or days so I havenít found it to be easy so when I decided I needed someone I wanted it to be someone I could rely on and know it was going to work. I remember when I was a student in Mexico this was a problem, I mean a professor who is teaching kinematic modeling right now so I looked him up and I saw that he had done some work on data, prosthetic limbs, so I said ok that might work, so I call him up and he was really excited about the project so we started just like that without any perspectives of getting funding or anything more than maybe just publications and then once we got started and things started to work out, I started looking for more funding opportunities and that is where I found the Nexus program and we applied and we got the grants so that is how it started.

They asked me how is this work how is that works how are things work in respect to the current political situation. I explained to them so they have no fear. But if you look at the larger general cultural sense I think academic will be much more willing to but that other side might be intimidating like well I donít know maybe because the US is so ugly these days so the people in Mexico might treat me poorly or something like that. I donít think it is true but I can see how people think that like.

Yeah, it can go either direction but I think that like I said in general the academic would tend to say you know what I would rather help Mexico given all the horrible things we hear coming out these days than completely abandoned. But when push comes to shove and things really getting done this and that I donít really know. Also the economic and environment and the way the university being funded and other stuff certainly doesnít help. They will have to open more very direct programs like we want to do in Latin American you know investment and interchange. They will have to funding something like that and I donít see that necessary coming above the horizon.

I will continue to collaborate with Brazil. However, Iíll be much more focus on people I considered as personal friends. Or people I can trust. For example, people who I worked with in Brazil I considered them as friends. I like personally trust people in Mexico the same thing. Iíll try much less so now me personally at the Mexican institutional level because I donít see a lot of hope there. On the US side, Iím hoping there could be funding help stuff like that.

At the institutional level, like I said I think people in the US side are embarrassed academically types, intellectual types probably pretty embarrassed about the current state of affairs and if you put that to them, then they would say yes I would like to expand relationship with Mexico and Latin America. But when push comes to shove like that is money and time, I donít know much of a priority that would be.

Yeah I think you really need to focus on the cultural and nature in the US institutions and the Mexican institutions at that structural level. The personal is always interesting but you can have personal war and family that exists but the bigger institutional prerogatives I see what is going to ultimately control or not and so they can do it kind of like a piece meal the way it has been done between individual institution and individual university and stuff like that but if there is not a larger scale kind ofÖfor example NSF? has the historically black college and university funding mechanism very specific to a specific group of people that have been discriminated againstÖyou could imagine something like Latin American research funding or even Mexico for that matter. You can imagine NSF for some other large or federal scale organizations opening up something like that. That would help, but how possible and realistic that is I donít know. The US, the continue kind of for lack of a better word corporatization of our university that depend on donors, depend on big business that kind of stuff is very detrimental. I think in general Mexico there is still socially support universities are free, students get scholarship. They donít graduate debts like the US, like most places in the world. So I think that culturally itís going to beÖfor me I can easily buy equipment in Mexico because itís not hard but to do that and justify in the US and then to collaborate with Mexico is very difficult. The US is much richer but they donít have that kind of mechanism in placed. I say that to my colleagues in the US and I get like blank stares what are you talking about. I was like look in Mexico we can do that easily. For what they donít understand in the US is like look you get your Mexican funding how canít you pay my salary. You donít do that in Mexico you get pay your salary or your research by your institution you donít have to pay your salary or grants and thatís all the US people donít understand that in the Mexican side. So there are less likely to doÖthey said hey you want a cute experiment youíre going to install equipment here do this and that is neatÖletís look at the data but I canít spend anytime on it because I didnít get pay and thatís very detrimental. So I say well okay look I get pay you donít have to pay me anything you do your NSF grantÖIím working with a guy from Harvard right now, he doesnít pay me anything because I get paid. So I help him do his research I get on the paper, they are very interesting itís my area so Iím helping him with that but he doesnít has to pay me anything. Now if I get him on one of my scholarship, now he will be like how are you going to fund my students, how are you going to do, how are you going to do thatÖso I canít. Again thatís kind of cultural institutional. Those things donít help so there have to some types of funding that understand those institutional funding. As far as I know, there is none set up in that respect. Did you followed what Iím saying?

So, when I moved to here and I worked at the Colegio La Frontera Norte, all those years, I lived in the United States for personal reasons. So I was travelling from the USA  San Diego - Tijuana for more than 11 years, and my commitment with the Colegio La Frontera Norte wasÖ

But the border became more and more complex and the institution the Colegio La Frontera Norte went to some crisis, and by then, my age was a determining factor to ask about how I would continue my life. It was not what I would like, but more what shall I do.

Also, my life happened all the time in the United States. I have this international commute daily for all these years, more than 11 years. 
The border became more complex over the years, and I remember some times, I used to cross twice a day. In the morning, and in the evening, if I have things to do in the evening.

My research and my teaching has always been what I consider transborder, or binational, so whenever I can, I help. I was the director of thesis, dissertation adviser, or teaching a course, or participating in research  at the Colegio de La Frontera Norte, my former institution. And I try to bring together these two institutions, especially through the exchange of  studentsÖ to educate them by national, by cultural, by the transborder nature of the region.

So, then is when I started looking for jobs in the United States and I was very lucky to find a job here in the San Diego area, which has allowed me not to move to another part of the United States.
So I started working here at San Diego State University, but I also maintained my professional relationship with the Colegio La Frontera Norte de MexicoÖ My research and my teaching has always been what I consider transborder, or binational, so whenever I can, I help. I was the director of thesis, dissertation adviser, or teaching a course, or participating in research  at the Colegio de La Frontera Norte, my former institution. And I try to bring together these two institutions, especially through the exchange of  studentsÖ to educate them by national, by cultural, by the transborder nature of the region. 
So, this has been pretty much the reason why I have been doing this kind of collaboration. 
I know that many otherÖ I do not about Mexican, but Latin American scholars in the United States will try to make the effort to sort of  connect with Latin American institutes, academic institutes, but in my case is  very natural because of the location my residence, and the location of my two institutions that have been collaborating in a very intense way for almost 20 years.

Dr. Ojeda. When you were in the Colegio La Frontera the Mexico, were you already collaborating with scholars in the United States?
 
Yes, because of the Colegio La Frontera Norte is an institution created by the Mexican government to develop research, develop data that allowed the Mexican federal governmentÖ

So the nature of the institution of institution doing research that informs the binational dimension of the USA Mexico border, and consequently, I participated in multiple projects that implied collaboration with USA institutions.
One that was particularly important over the years for me was with the University of Arizona, that was associated with the women reproductive healthÖ because I am a demographer and sociologist, so everything that has to do with family, including reproduction and consequently, women health, and dimension and gender. We developed a consortium between USA and Mexican institutes. There were three mexican institutions  and two USA universities. University of Arizona, and USD university, and in the Mexican side, [there were] the Colegio La Frontera Norte, El Colegio de la Frontera Sur  en Chiapas, el Colegio de Sodona.  So that was one. 
So, it was from the very beginning.
Also, when I started living in this region, I was fascinated by this binational flow of population.

Well. knocking doors, through conferences. Also, the Colegio La Frontera Norte has a very intense relationships with universities in the United States and also in Europe. So, it was relatively easy the interaction between USA scholars. In that particularly case, it was extremely intense.

And the dynamic of USA university is totally different from the dynamic of the Colegio La Frontera Norte de Mexico. As you know as an institution, at least the major focus of my university is education. Research is required but it is not necessarily  the main purpose. El Colegio La Frontera de Mexico is exactly the opposite. That was the other factor why I stopped pursuing that [my attempt to pursuing collaboration in Spain and Morroco].
Now, Mexico and Spain, I did not care much about that.  Because there are multiple mexican scholars working on that direction.  
So I was more into these transborder collaboration, geographic units that facilitated the mobility between ordinary individuals.

Well. It was a very interest project at some point that was developed by a Mexican scholar in the Colegio La Frontera, Norte Ju... invited me to collaborate with him. His plan was to collaborate with many USA universities  in collaboration about socio demographic research on USA Mexican borders. And I discovered through that project,  that bring together  American universities was not that easy, , because they see each other as competing. They want to be the primary institution in the relationship with the Mexican institutions. So I noticed that at least in that particular case, that the american universities that were invited to th  the table started in a very polite way to compete with each other among American institutions.

So, I see more collaboration these days than back then. They did not want competition. We have to understand that american universities start to develop this type of collaboration as a way to pursue funding money, and you cannot three PI institutions. 
At least, back then, the foundation did not allow that. It was always one primary institution in one country, and another primary institution in the other country. At this point, I do not know if they allow more than one primary institutions in different countries, but back then. So Arizona did not want competition.
