n both cases, probably the most important is to persuade your the administrators at your institutions regarding what you are doing is  worthy. Obviously, you need their support, becase you have  many levels of possible interactions. What is most important is when you have ordinary faculty that were  interested in collaboration because they are the ones who will start moving the pieces, doing the research, talking to people, looking for funds. But they  need to persuade administrators from the department chair, the dean, the provost, etc. And that works in both countries, and you would say in any country. 
So, sometimes the administrators, they are always thinking about money. They are always thinking about what they will get from this collaboration. They are very supportive with the faculty, but when they really see an opportunity to bring something to their own collaboration, but always becomes money, they give you the full support. They will never say no, but then, you do not see any kind of concrete support. 
I think this is the challenge, the most important challenge for any american or mexican scholar or any other ordinary faculty interested in the collaboration. 
One of the reasons why I became so successful in the consortium was because there were administrators interested in the collaboration, and they gave us full support.

For example, one reason that my PhD advisor was so interested on international collaboration, it's that there are other funds abroad that we don't really have access to as a research community in the US because we don't have those collaborations. At that point, both the funding from NSF and [inaudible 00:11:35] have been declining here in the US. So, by seeking international collaborations, you can actually have access to other economic sources. That will afford for funding students and keep the research program going.

So in those cases, the collaboration gets really hard, even if there is economic motivators, or the university is pushing for it. I don't think the individual will actually make it happen. At the end what is required is a lot of time investment. Sometimes on initiatives that you don't really know if they're going to lead you somewhere in the next few years. A lot of these things is just trusting that something will come up out of it. Some personalities they won't be able to do that.

Sometimes also you have to consider the academic reputation of the collaborators. Here in the US, a lot of times people are just familiar with the US news report, which usually does a very poor job ranking universities abroad. There are a lot of good universities abroad that they ... They're far down in the rankings, but they're, I will say US centric, so in those cases then it makes more difficult to make a case for your chair, for your dean, for your institution, to let you work with that collaborator, with that contrast in mind.

I think it's usually individual faculty. And I think that a good way to start things is sometimes if the institution does make the decision to go and collaborate with whatever partner, but the faculty is not onboard, so you don't have an individual champion, it usually doesn't go very far. On the other hand, if there is one individual champion that is trying and trying and trying but the institution doesn't support it, then that individual probably will just quit on the surface.

I would say really low. I mean, well to start with there is not many faculty with a Hispanic background. I have seen recent reports from the University of San Diego from Olivia Greene, and I think they were, out of all the US faculty there, I think like 600 and something that they have a Hispanic background, and usually most of us, we are not born here in the US. So the Mexican-Americans, it seems like they are not really going for faculty positions. Since you don't have that, then it gets difficult to really implement collaborations with Mexico, because people don't realize the value of Mexico as a partner.

Well, the first one is that the politicians, they need to start selling Mexico as a partner, rather than a competitor. That would be one, just softening the public opinion towards Mexico. The other one is to have a better education of why exactly Mexico should be a partner and not a competitor. What is the effect of educating the general population on what are the benefits to them, from actually partnering with Mexico.

Well, the first one is that the politicians, they need to start selling Mexico as a partner, rather than a competitor. That would be one, just softening the public opinion towards Mexico. The other one is to have a better education of why exactly Mexico should be a partner and not a competitor. What is the effect of educating the general population on what are the benefits to them, from actually partnering with Mexico.

So one of the things they usually keep saying that Mexico is stealing the jobs, but then they usually don't complete the story on what jobs are going where, what jobs are being originating here in the US as part of the Mexican partnership. What is the effect of that on the everyday life? Sure, for example we can bring home the jobs back in the US, but then the cost of goods in the US would start increasing, so then how are we going to deal with that? So there will be all these secondary things that usually don't get included when talk about Mexico. So one of the things there will be to educate the population better on the benefits and disadvantages of doing business with Mexico. From there, then there can be a trickle down effect. The society, the potential funders, having a more friendly vision of Mexico, and the opportunities that they can be developed with that.

I think one important thing is not to only focus on academic collaboration, traditional academic collaboration, when the output is the paper or research project. There are so many other things that the connections are already made, like the politics the economics. Those ones are already made, but we're not really connecting them to academia. I think a lot of universities throughout the US, they can actually reach out to the local industry, and I'm very positive that the local industry will actually connections to Mexico. From there see what are the needs of that local industry have, how they connect to the needs from Mexico, and then figuring out how exactly a university can fit into that scene. Because, in terms of academic reputation, not many universities will make the cut, or not many Mexican universities will make the cut, because we are kind of blinded by the rankings. But then from the other point of view, seeing those universities as a partner to support the industry connections. There are a lot of them already. I will say not only focus on academic collaboration but taking all these other things into consideration.

I like and I think you know going back to the first question, I think that academic collaboration should be or at least that is why I try to do, as horizontal as possible. Or provably someone has more experience in the topic, but I think the aim of academic collaboration is that you bring the strength of everyone or at least that has been my experience. So thatís how I make it, through emails, meetings and a lot of time, spending time defining our goals.

Not at all. I would say, I consider myself an educator and specialist in education, in many fields, in ed curriculum development, you know, all the way to professional development of teahcers, like pre-school education etc etc. However, since the community with the one I am collaborating with itís the one setting up the agenda I feel that sometimes they had took me into a different field. For example, even though I am interested  in the development of education, formal education in the community and language vitalization, and specifically about Maya, they are very interested in tourism and archeology, so it has pushed to know more about these other fields like tourism and archeology because they want to know more about that and at the same time is not like Iím sacrificing my own topics but it is a negotiation like ok  they are interested in that,  letís honor those interests, but also these are my interests, and thatís why I think it is a collaboration because itís not just, Iím gonna follow your agenda but we are negotiating our agenda all the time. So, it has taken me out, these collaborations has take me out of my field of expertise.

exico was selected, let me answer that one first, was selected because is my country, is my research interest, I wanted to develop my agenda in Mexico basically. I have work with different, also here in the States but my main goal is to develop research in Mexico, thatís one. Two how it did develop with these other people? I think it was just an accident. One, is the funding I receive through Penn to do summer research. The second one is the Penn Cultural Heritage Center, which has believe in my work, because they are more focused on archeological work, but Iíve placed education in the agenda, and language in the agenda, and I think Iím the first educator that has been funded through the museum of Archeology to do research, I believe that. I found my space there and they have given me money for that, and that has been great. Funding is fundamental, funding has allow me to, when I do research in Mexico with people that I collaborate with, non-necessarily in higher education institutions, but with a museum that I collaborate with in the community, that I can pay for things. I think some of the factors have been my partnerships here in the States. So, even if we have this project between the Penn Cultural Heritage Center and Mexico many of the people that are here in the States, at the Penn Cultural Heritage Center, I donít know maybe this is something that is wrong but I do believe and I talk to a lot of people because they are not from Mexico, sometimes I think they think that Mexican academia, or Mexican academics have not the same quality or do not follow the same rigorous standards, which I think is false. So, sometimes I have been the one pushing for more collaborations with Mexican academics, believing in Mexican academics, because Iím Mexican, because I have been trained in Mexico on the undergrad, and Iíve seen amazing research, but because is not in English is just not worth it, so fighting for me has been internal in terms of Penn, people not believing that, people here in the States are like oh yeah they are local gate keepers, but is not local gate keepers they are collaborators, and they also produce an amazing stuff, is just that you donít validate it because it doesnít come from an Ivy League school, or a school from the States. So thatís been a factor, with the one I always fighted, always.

They are, actually my department has a very strong relationship, collaborative with Kings College in England. Again, I think they are interested because its Kings College. Its no num (21:01) is not la Universidad del estado de Paraguay, or whatever, o la CatÛlica de Chile, or like UBA, or something like that. So, I think they are driven, and maybe Iím wrong, but I think they are driven by status. Rather than by, considering than many of us who are international are working on those types of institutions, like we have the same  rigour that we learned here and that we learned in our countries and now we are developing lines of research over there, but maybe is also because I feel at least in my program, the school of education is very American centric, is US centric, rather than international so that is why I think there is no a lot of intentions to work with another countries.

Oh yeah, I see the question know! I prefer peer related, definitely, person to person. Like you know, institutions are people, so I wanna talk, like even with my current collaboration right now, you know in the town where I work, there are different researchers from different institutions. We are not under the shadow of our institution, but we are who we are and then we work at an institution. But we didnít have to ask  permission  to the institution, we are not depending on the institutionsí funding, but its more about our energy, the energy that we wanna spend in our collaboration and is a peer to peer thing, then you know when we write an article we have to write about where we are right now working, but is not that our institutions have been funding us, like all of us are looking for funding independently and I think that those peer to peer collaborations are more real. Probably institution to institution collaborations are more sustainable, right? Because there would be economic channels there all the time, it doesnít matter who is there, there is going to be collaborations between institutions, but at the same time those collaborations are done by people and maybe one of those professors leaves, you know that collaboration is gonna end between institutions. I donít know if that makes sense,

Because there would be economic channels there all the time, it doesnít matter who is there, there is going to be collaborations between institutions, but at the same time those collaborations are done by people and maybe one of those professors leaves, you know that collaboration is gonna end between institutions. I donít know if that makes sense,

Right, I think first of all, people that are interested in it and that have time to invest in the creation of this you know like I feel that as academics, having a clear agenda of why we want to do this, right? So its like, as an R1 institution Penn is ok, we are gonna create like a center for collaboration between Mexico and the US or Penn and UNAM, I donít know, so like from the beginning, what types of schools are we gonna be targeting in Mexico, which ones are going to be targeted here in the States, what types of results do we wanna have? Like do we wanna have a seminar every year? Or eventually after two years we wanna have an international mini-congress in Mexico or something here at Penn? Are looking to bring professors from there or like take professors from here over there? So, I think you need a clear agenda, people that are invested in it, that have time.

I think that the main collaborations that Iíve been part of, the main factor, again in this type of institutions is knowledge production and understand, seen if like things that are happening here in the States are happening also in Mexico or in other countries, so I think that is the main factor that drives people and the other one I guess it might be more for Mexican institutions but is a very neoliberal idea, but its like you know, it is training people in the States and there are a better product when they go back to Mexico, like supposedly they are branded, but thatís a very neoliberal idea.

I think it will, from what I know again, this is something that I just have read from the news, and something that Iím scared off as a PhD student that is under a Visa. Oh! Wait, no, of course it has been affected. I didnít even get a fellowship, sorry for the silence there. Because the current administration they cancelled the InterAmerican Scholarship, Fellowship, and this is something itís a fellowship that was sponsored by the InterAmerican Bank of the development, and as soon as Trump arrived, he cancelled the fellowship. I know that because I was the last  cohort that applied and we didnít even get into account for it, so it got cancelled. So it has affected the relationship, and that fellowship that I was applying for was all about collaborations with institutions in Mexico with the community that Iím working in, etc. etc. And I was not even considered, even though I applied and everything, itís over, they are not gonna give money for this. So, I think that has affected the development of Science, between Mexico, Penn, the States and Latin America.

I see, I feel, collaborations depend a lot on people and the interest of people, just how I said it before. I feel that it depends a lot on the types of people that are at the institutions. You know, Penn been such a white institution are interested in other type of stuff. There are not a lot of international people, at least not at the Graduate School of Education and many of the international people are most of the time interested in American topics, in US topics, you know you have a couple of programs like International Educational Development who have more of an international agenda, but even professors there are interested of things that happen here in the States and they want to give it an international scope. So I feel that it depends a lot on the institutions. You go to California and you have all the UC system, lots of institutions that are interested in Mexico-US relationships. You go to Chicago and because of the population that lives there, you have a lot of people that are interested not only on US things, like Latin America, things on the Middle East. So I think it depends a lot on the population that universities are hiring. Again, like yesterday, Penn was ranked number two in the world. I say that to my parents and my friends and they donít know it. I prefer to say that I went to Columbia for my masterís cause they know it, you know it makes more sense, so in a way I think it depends a lot on having people that are interested in Mexico. Like if you hire people that are interested in Mexico, they are gonna start making those relationships better, but I donít know if Penn creating a center for Mexican studies will be successful, because if you donít have people interested in doing research there, I donít think itís successful. When I was doing my masterís at Teachers College at Columbia I was part of the creation of the Center for Mexican studies with Claudio Lomnitz who is an anthropologist over there and itís a very successful center right now. We started as students guided by him, but now is something that is receiving institutional funding, but it was because people interested on a research agenda in Mexico wanted to come together every two weeks, bring academics, apply for fellowships and then eventually that became something. But I think that if you donít have people interested on it, it would be a waste of money, if you have the funding, what I said before, the first factor would be to have funding, but I guess the first factor would be having people that are interested and then after that funding.

But I think that if you donít have people interested on it, it would be a waste of money, if you have the funding, what I said before, the first factor would be to have funding, but I guess the first factor would be having people that are interested and then after that funding.

I see, I feel, collaborations depend a lot on people and the interest of people, just how I said it before. I feel that it depends a lot on the types of people that are at the institutions. You know, Penn been such a white institution are interested in other type of stuff. There are not a lot of international people, at least not at the Graduate School of Education and many of the international people are most of the time interested in American topics, in US topics, you know you have a couple of programs like International Educational Development who have more of an international agenda, but even professors there are interested of things that happen here in the States and they want to give it an international scope. So I feel that it depends a lot on the institutions. You go to California and you have all the UC system, lots of institutions that are interested in Mexico-US relationships. You go to Chicago and because of the population that lives there, you have a lot of people that are interested not only on US things, like Latin America, things on the Middle East. So I think it depends a lot on the population that universities are hiring. Again, like yesterday, Penn was ranked number two in the world. I say that to my parents and my friends and they donít know it. I prefer to say that I went to Columbia for my masterís cause they know it, you know it makes more sense, so in a way I think it depends a lot on having people that are interested in Mexico. Like if you hire people that are interested in Mexico, they are gonna start making those relationships better, but I donít know if Penn creating a center for Mexican studies will be successful, because if you donít have people interested in doing research there, I donít think itís successful. This is challenging, right? But I think that with any international project is important, and you know, the US been so dominant, I think something important would be like if any collaboration is created with any country in this case Mexico, it would be important to understand the reality, like have people that are local, like local academics, academics that are really invested in it. I think that would be very important, not trying to invent the wheel. Trying to understand Mexico US relationships in terms of academics or academia I think, I think Iím not saying anything. I donít have any other idea.

I tend to see academic collaboration in a very broad fashion. It might mean institution, institution, individual faculty member to individual faculty member, it can include faculty members from one institution collaborating with students from another. In other words, it implies at least two parties, but the nature of those parties and the nature their identities are open to circumstance and context.

I tend to see academic collaboration in a very broad fashion. It might mean institution, institution, individual faculty member to individual faculty member, it can include faculty members from one institution collaborating with students from another. In other words, it implies at least two parties, but the nature of those parties and the nature their identities are open to circumstance and context.

I tend to think of collaborative projects as projects that involve two peoples or two entities two institutions working in some fashion together towards a common end as opposed to a solo project would be me pursuing something which I saw perhaps as productive for my career or my profession but didn’t necessarily involve someone else or some other entity.

Actually what I can do this, I have a list of about 29 different kinds of collaborations that I have done over the years, not separate collaborations but different kinds. In some cases for example I might be working with faculty members in Mexico to arrange to bring faculty members or others to the US on a speaking tour, at another moment, I might be setting up a project to take a group of students to Mexico. Third instance might be with research and fourth instance might be with publications etc. 
Probably the easiest thing to do is just to send you a list of these different kinds of collaborations because it covers about 28 or 29 different possibilities.

Those represent the general categories but beyond that one gets into a fairly extensive array of creating opportunities for institutions for example working with one of the institutions to create training programs both in Mexico and in the US to train their faculty. Well is that institutional or does it focus on individual faculty? Working with another institution so that one of tis grad students co-authors a paper with me and she presents it a conference in Europe. Well on one respect that’s individual, on another respect, its working with an individual. That’s why I say there’s an enormous array and variations of configurations here.

I did have one question for you. I looked at the title of the project: faculty-led US-Mexico collaborations. I can read that as faculty led meaning faculty initiatives as opposed to institutional initiatives or I can read that as in the context of all this is about institutions simply one has faculty as sort of the leading edge rather than the initiators because what can happen is that there are faculty-led initiatives that does not necessarily involve institutions. So when I looked at that I probably have 60 faculty led programs that I have created when I organized students, I organized activities in the field, that do not involve institutions in any kind of structured or sustained fashion. But I also have things and activities that have had a strong institutional focus. That was something that I wrestled with a little bit. At the end how I read the statement and the letter I said well probably they are thinking more about institutional relationships, which is what the book chapter that I sent you covers.

Yes. And as we go through the question all I ask of you is that you give me some indication of whether you want a response tilted in the direction of what are institutional issues as opposed to those that are faculty-led because having done literally dozens of individual faculty led groups but also having worked with institutions to create, manage and oversee programs – I have done that for institutions but I have also done these in a more free-willy fashion being some body until someone one says no, I take it as yes.

That’s a really interesting question because my field of study is political science. I have never taken a public administration course in my life but years ago a benevolent deity, trickster creator or somebody stuck me in the field of public administration or administrative, payroll purposes and I have never been able to get back to political science. Just as in Mexico, I spent 14 years as an adjunct professor of industrial engineering, I have no background in engineering, but it was convenient for the university to put me in that department so that I could have a faculty status to be able to grade students, supervise Mexican students, so.

Oh you have touched on a very tender subject. I happen to be part of a corporate merger between two institutional programs so when I came to Portland State University in 1997, there was absolutely no international activity except for a handful of students in the middle east taking a degree in public administration. At one point the department chair actually reduced my salary because I was involved in international activities. And at another point another chair refused to give me credit for publications because they were in Spanish. So, there was absolutely zero support for doing international things. That was 1997. 2014, the national association of schools in public affairs and administration rated Portland state Master of Public Administration as one of four in the US that was exemplary in terms of their international offerings. So, in a period of essentially 16-17 years we went from practically 0 to not only myself being involved but I have colleagues who are heavily involved in Vietnam, Korea, Japan, China and in Cuba. So, what you think of this as an academic version of ???’s long war. We just had a long march from 0 activities to now at least one quarter of the department with active international engagement

I think it’s fair to say that. Part of it is as we have more faculty and greater range of activities, our own institution–as this is true of many universities in the US – more or less discovered the notion of internationalization. There has not necessarily been a strong embrace. There has been a benign neglect. And for works in Asia, there has been university interest because the senior administration sees Asia as a place to produce international students for us and because there has been a certain amount of money from American companies such as intel here in Oregon to help encourage and promote that. So there has been changes in external circumstances as well as a gradual shift in perspective. Today, no body turns up their nose when I publish in Spanish as well as in English, at least that was not the case a dozen years ago.

Long long ago, I actually started my international studies as an undergraduate in Iran. And that was a semester abroad. When I went to graduate school at Stanford I was focused on Latin American and was planning to do a dissertation in Guatemala. But I knew very little about doing field work in rural settings and at that time Stanford’s Anthropology department had a field training program for doing anthropological research based in Oaxaca Mexico. I was able to go to Oaxaca on that program, and in 1968, I returned to Oaxaca to do my dissertation research in Oaxaca. And at that time had some peripheral contact with a couple of the universities. Because I had followed up for more than 50 years. I have worked in Oaxaca. I got to know many faculty, graduate students…In 1991, I started working with one of the universities in Oaxaca first as an academic specialist and then they asked if I could help them strengthen their master’s program and start a Ph.D. program. So in 1994-5, 1995-6, I invested a lot of time through a full bright working on that and from that, grew one set of collaborations

So in 1994-5, 1995-6, I invested a lot of time through a full bright working on that and from that, grew one set of collaborations

Simultaneously, but completely separate, I’ve been working with other scholars in Oaxaca since the mid 1980s on various kinds of collaborative projects that are non-university based but work with a variety of nonprofits and Mexico government agencies so there has been two streams one being university grounded and another being research collaboration grounded. 

And then there’s a third stream which is I worked with colleagues to create a nonprofit research center and library in Oaxaca- called the institution XX which has the best library collection on contemporary Oaxaca anywhere in the world in Oaxaca and I’m the executive director of that. So that has brought me into overlapping but also different pools of people in academic institutions.

Simultaneously, but completely separate, I’ve been working with other scholars in Oaxaca since the mid 1980s on various kinds of collaborative projects that are non-university based but work with a variety of nonprofits and Mexico government agencies so there has been two streams one being university grounded and another being research collaboration grounded. 

And then there’s a third stream which is I worked with colleagues to create a nonprofit research center and library in Oaxaca- called the institution XX which has the best library collection on contemporary Oaxaca anywhere in the world in Oaxaca and I’m the executive director of that. So that has brought me into overlapping but also different pools of people in academic institutions.

Sure. For example, probably my most consistent non-university collaboration has been with Mexico’s national institute of anthropology and history known in its Mexican acronym as INA. INA is roughly the equivalent of the national park services in the U.S. and I have worked with a cadre of archeologists and other social scientists there on a whole array of projects that range from helping with the design and preparation of two requests to UNESCO for world heritage site status for different places to training programs for both Mexican professionals from INA and the US parks services, so joint operations with them, and then, more specific projects such as helping to train people from community museums so that they can act as hosts to visiting groups that pay for opportunities to get into those rural communities and the payments support the community museums. So an extensive array of training actives, research activities, program development activities that have no grounding in any university setting but bring me into contact with everybody from rural peasants to managers of programs in Mexico city.

Sure. For example, probably my most consistent non-university collaboration has been with Mexico’s national institute of anthropology and history known in its Mexican acronym as INA. INA is roughly the equivalent of the national park services in the U.S. and I have worked with a cadre of archeologists and other social scientists there on a whole array of projects that range from helping with the design and preparation of two requests to UNESCO for world heritage site status for different places to training programs for both Mexican professionals from INA and the US parks services, so joint operations with them, and then, more specific projects such as helping to train people from community museums so that they can act as hosts to visiting groups that pay for opportunities to get into those rural communities and the payments support the community museums. So an extensive array of training actives, research activities, program development activities that have no grounding in any university setting but bring me into contact with everybody from rural peasants to managers of programs in Mexico city.

That’s a good question and probably what is a critical factor here is that the prolonged continuity. In other words, had I done all of this in Serbia 50 years ago or Malaysia..if I  followed the same pattern of continuity and engagement across five decades I think I could have had a somewhat similar trajectory or career…Having done this in Mexico and being able to now working with the adult grandchildren of people I worked with 0years ago. What that means is an important access that greatly lubricates any kind of interactions even if I am not doing something with a university. I’m frequently running into people who were my Mexican students 50 years ago or I’m working with the children of a weaver that I bout weavings from 40 years age. All of this adds together and there is a cumulative effect that frequently institutions, particularly US institutions, that simply do not understand because the focus is much more on formal transactions and formal agreements. In the Mexico the emphasis is much more on continuing and depth of relationships. At least that’s true in Oaxaca.

Well one factor that has been very, very important is recognizing that these relationships flourish most effectively under reciprocity. In other words, I take groups of students to Mexico but simply out of my own time and energy, I created a whole array of opportunities for Mexican students to come to the US. Well, not only do the students benefit from and appreciate that but their faculty do because it gives faculty a certain muster, their institutions do because it helps the institutions internationalize which is a concern in Mexico just as it is here. And frequently there are challenges on resources. So I’ve worked with one of our graduate students, former graduate student, at Portland State to create and whatabouts to a nonprofit organizations that raises money to bring women from a university up here for a training programs and managing nonprofit organizations. The idea behind that is to help give them motivation to stay in university instead of dropping out. So there is simply an enormous array of looking for ways to facilitate and create reciprocity even to such things as – and this is strictly the way academics work – but who gets first authorship in a publication. And if you say, here we have three authors, who will it be? Generally, I will make sure that one of my Mexican colleagues is listed as first author because that contributes a certain amount of muster and prestige to them. I am old guy, I don’t need that. It’s immaterial for me but it can very helpful for them. O looking for ways to work within the cultural context to ensure that there is reciprocity. And that’s something that’s very hard for American institutions to understand because deans and provosts and the like are always asking what’s in it for us. But you have to recognize there has to be something in it for the other side. And that has been one of the reasons I’ve been so successful with these things because I always try to make sure that there is something for the other side and that’s something that is very visible.

A big part of it is again the continuity because as you spend more time with people and in the same settings you begin to see not necessarily what people tell you but what they really do value. So I have people who are not only my counterparts but they are my friends, so I see this through those eyes. Part of it has been a willingness to work within their institutional contexts even when it may drive me nuts but to learn to recognize what it is that they confront because when you do that instead of saying “well I don’t know why you guys don’t do it this way. This is better.” Okay, what’s going on here that I should try to understand. Why is it that university X, the university is surrounded by a chain link fence and there are guards at the gates armed with rifles who will not let you out during the day. Well we don’t work that way in Portland state. So the question is what’s the thinking that generates that kind of system. You need to be willing to ask that rather than being judgmental. And that’s something that goes all the way back to my experiences in Iran to ask what’s happening, why is this developing in this way, rather than to make judgements in an instinctively American framework.

Okay and part of it is me trying to understand your frame of reference. Because if your frame of reference is Mexico, I can say statements like just incredible bureaucracy and a tendency towards an atmosphere of control and things like that. But if I were to make comments about what is it in the US – and here I am talking more specifically about my own institution - back when I was teaching in Lewison Clark college before our programs was moved here to Portland State, the university was very open to wanting international programs. That was one of its strong points and it really encouraged both students and faculty to be engaged. When I came here to Portland State, the attitude was 180 degrees opposite. No why do you want to do international stuff. Our constituency is here in Oregon, or Portland. International activities don’t mean anything to us. And what I have encountered even though academically Portland state has become more open about the international side, administratively, bureaucratically, it has become markedly less so. As an example, when I started international programs, there were no guidelines whatsoever. There were some programs abroad, but they tended to be through other state universities, and nobody paid much attention to it. I started doing these programs short-term programs in Mexico and largely invented what I was doing. Now, there is an entire monograph that tells us what, when and how it has to be done, and in the entire academic program is secondary to compliance with an extensive set of bureaucratic requirements. Now I teach bureaucracy I understand this, and I understand the university more than anything else is concerned about managing risk. But the way it manages risk creates incredible impediments to doing programs simply because it adds significantly to the cost. It requires programming so far in advance that we lose the opportunity to take advantage of the very opportunities that experiences can create. So what has happened over time, and I can tell you all kinds of stories but I will not because it will upset my institution, but what has happened over time is the bureaucratic framework has to a large degree frozen and marginalized the academic opportunity, and it’s really unfortunate, but that’s a decision made by people at a higher salary grade, and although I live with it a certain aspect and try to deal with in the margins as I can but for example, we are expected now to work through service providers, essentially companies or institutions that sell these services for logistics, organizations, etc. I have all of that in place. It’s simply an additional financial burden on our students, and that it turn, excludes some students from being able to participate, but my institution is less concerned about that then making sure that it has a formal structure they can point to and say that’s our provider. So, that’s the way the institution wants to do it. It’s unfortunate, but that’s why Portland state is better known than it once was for international activities but nowhere near as well as it could be if we were less encumbered by administrative process, hence the chapter I sent you.

Okay and part of it is me trying to understand your frame of reference. Because if your frame of reference is Mexico, I can say statements like just incredible bureaucracy and a tendency towards an atmosphere of control and things like that. But if I were to make comments about what is it in the US – and here I am talking more specifically about my own institution - back when I was teaching in Lewison Clark college before our programs was moved here to Portland State, the university was very open to wanting international programs. That was one of its strong points and it really encouraged both students and faculty to be engaged. When I came here to Portland State, the attitude was 180 degrees opposite. No why do you want to do international stuff. Our constituency is here in Oregon, or Portland. International activities don’t mean anything to us. And what I have encountered even though academically Portland state has become more open about the international side, administratively, bureaucratically, it has become markedly less so. As an example, when I started international programs, there were no guidelines whatsoever. There were some programs abroad, but they tended to be through other state universities, and nobody paid much attention to it. I started doing these programs short-term programs in Mexico and largely invented what I was doing. Now, there is an entire monograph that tells us what, when and how it has to be done, and in the entire academic program is secondary to compliance with an extensive set of bureaucratic requirements. Now I teach bureaucracy I understand this, and I understand the university more than anything else is concerned about managing risk. But the way it manages risk creates incredible impediments to doing programs simply because it adds significantly to the cost. It requires programming so far in advance that we lose the opportunity to take advantage of the very opportunities that experiences can create. So what has happened over time, and I can tell you all kinds of stories but I will not because it will upset my institution, but what has happened over time is the bureaucratic framework has to a large degree frozen and marginalized the academic opportunity, and it’s really unfortunate, but that’s a decision made by people at a higher salary grade, and although I live with it a certain aspect and try to deal with in the margins as I can but for example, we are expected now to work through service providers, essentially companies or institutions that sell these services for logistics, organizations, etc. I have all of that in place. It’s simply an additional financial burden on our students, and that it turn, excludes some students from being able to participate, but my institution is less concerned about that then making sure that it has a formal structure they can point to and say that’s our provider. So, that’s the way the institution wants to do it. It’s unfortunate, but that’s why Portland state is better known than it once was for international activities but nowhere near as well as it could be if we were less encumbered by administrative process, hence the chapter I sent you.

Yeah. Let me put it this way. There is interest, and the best way I can describe this is globally, Portland State has somewhat over 400 international agreements for different kinds of collaborations. Of those 400, I think 420, roughly 75% are dead letter nothing ever happens. IN the case of Mexico, the most vigorous participation is the participation that we have in Oaxaca, and we can have much more if I did not have to struggle so much with the bureaucratic side of this. But the bureaucratic side is what keeps a lot of our administrators employed and I understand that. Okay what this means is we could be doing more. We have institutions that are interested in working with us simply because we do have the capacity to be responsive, we just don’t have the organizational flexibility to be responsive. And the other factor in this is it goes back to something that I mentioned about Asia. We can go back to Korea, Japan or China and see large numbers of relatively speaking of students who would like to come to Portland. In Mexico, when you are looking to the US, Oregon is not the place that immediately comes to mind. They are more likely to go to California, Texas or big-name schools such as the University of Pennsylvania. And Pennsylvania used to have a program in Oaxaca.

Sure. And I understand that we are a tuition-drive institution and we can persuade people to come and they pay tuition, we are delighted. That’s not going to happen in any significant way for Mexico. Now we’ve been able to recruit a few students that are funded by Mexico’s equivalent of NSF. But that has been a very small pool and there is no organized process here for doing that. In fact, most of my trips to Mexico I pay for out of my own pocket. That’s the way these things are. But the university here does not say all right, here we will give you some materials or we would appreciate if you could set up a visit to A or a visit to B. If I do that out of my own initiative, that’s fine that’s very good. But nobody is going to pat me on the back, give me a gold star and remember me when faculty raises come through. That’s just the reality of it.

Well, a couple things. One would be a little more flexibility in terms of time so that I can go when it would be feasible and worthwhile in a Mexican sense rather than in terms of our calendar here. Those are structural details that needs to be addressed. Probably in a more general sense, it would be to have an administrative process here that took promotion of this as being valuable rather than control as being… because there is a huge difference between essentially responding to administrative expectations and okay go out and what can you do? How can you encourage this? What do you need in the way of... even just opening doors or not creating impediments rather than in order to do X you have all kinds of paperwork to attend to. It has to be managed within this kind of calendar. It has to be managed through people who have no experience with this but who are given the gate keeper status because they’ve been appointed to this position or that position. I mean and it’s nothing extraordinary, but I have, as an individual, more experience in managing international programs than our entire study abroad office combined. And yet, I have to structure what I do according to the expectations of that office which in turn, our conditioned by their experience with commercial providers. And so in a sense, there is more attention paid to the commercial providers than to our own faculty. And this is not the first time I’ve encountered these things. And I’ve had programs in Mexico and have statements coming from the study abroad office saying oh, Mexico is a dangerous place. Well, how do you know? We read the state department’s statements on this. Yes, the state department’s statements are based on a place 100 miles of way from where we are. Well, that’s the university works, and it will be great to have somebody who was more sensitive to that’s actually happening. And I’m sorry to burden you with all of this.

You are absolutely right. There is no golden formula, and the argument that I would make is – which is in some sense, self-serving, but also based on years of experience, is that what is necessary is investment in this across time. That’s the point about continuity. What matters in Mexico in most institutions is the sense of relationships that have developed, and the only way you develop those relationships is by being there. By being in communication. By doing things people in Mexican institutions see as being beneficial to them not just beneficial to us. It’s very difficult for an administrator in a resource-scarce institution like Portland State to say we are going to X, Y or Z which we think in the long run will be beneficial for us, but in the short-run is beneficial to an institution above.  But that’s not just Mexico. It could be anywhere.

I am used to working peer-to-peer. I have, as someone who has directed doctoral dissertations in Mexico, some of those people were my institutional peers who were in the process they were faculty trying to get a Ph.D. Their institution didn’t have money to send them abroad. We did it essentially locally. So working with them in a direct sense over time meant we developed share interests, we understood where we get into sensitive areas, I have found some of my Mexican colleagues to be just marvelous scholars, very supportive individuals. And I ‘ve found just as I find here in the US they will look for ways to cut corners or simply…they try to understand American universities through their lens just as we tend to look at Mexican universities through our lens.  So they have a really tough time sometimes understanding. For example, the lack of supervision here. Because faculty come and go. If I were in Oaxaca as a faculty member, I would have to sign in every morning with a fingerprint scan and being videotaped. And I would have to sing out the same way. Try to get away with that Penn and tell faculty you have to check in and out just like working at a coca cola bottling plant. Mexicans look at the freedom American faculty have and can’t understand it. They ask who is it that come around and checks to make sure you are in class. I don’t have to worry about that. If I don’t show up in class, I will have cadre of students complaining at the chairman’s office complaining we pay all this tuition and our faculty member is asleep in his office. Having invested huge amount of time learning to see the world through Mexican faculty eyes, to be able to work with them is, I am comfortable doing that. I am probably less comfortable working at the institutional level simply because I am accustomed to rather abrupt changes - who is the president, provost, dean or their equivalent – and you start all over again. There are people that I worked with easily for 25 years , I directed their doctoral dissertation 20 years ago, we published together. It’s a good relationship. Their kid have been up here and stayed at my house. I’ve sent students down there to work on some projects. Those faculty have come up here. That’s cool. And it’s a very productive relationship. So working with colleague sand learning to see the way their institutions work through their eyes greatly helps me when I am here in Portland trying to help our institution understand why assumptions people are making will simply not go anywhere and not be useful. And understanding when there are sometimes – I don’t talk about various dimension of this here simply because I know if I did somebody will say how can we make money out of that and that’s not the point. The point is being able to get access for our students when they are in Mexico. But see that’s seeing it through an academic rather than administrative perspective.

And understanding when there are sometimes – I don’t talk about various dimension of this here simply because I know if I did somebody will say how can we make money out of that and that’s not the point. The point is being able to get access for our students when they are in Mexico. But see that’s seeing it through an academic rather than administrative perspective.

I am used to working peer-to-peer. I have, as someone who has directed doctoral dissertations in Mexico, some of those people were my institutional peers who were in the process they were faculty trying to get a Ph.D. Their institution didn’t have money to send them abroad. We did it essentially locally. So working with them in a direct sense over time meant we developed share interests, we understood where we get into sensitive areas, I have found some of my Mexican colleagues to be just marvelous scholars, very supportive individuals. And I ‘ve found just as I find here in the US they will look for ways to cut corners or simply…they try to understand American universities through their lens just as we tend to look at Mexican universities through our lens.  So they have a really tough time sometimes understanding. For example, the lack of supervision here. Because faculty come and go. If I were in Oaxaca as a faculty member, I would have to sign in every morning with a fingerprint scan and being videotaped. And I would have to sing out the same way. Try to get away with that Penn and tell faculty you have to check in and out just like working at a coca cola bottling plant. Mexicans look at the freedom American faculty have and can’t understand it. They ask who is it that come around and checks to make sure you are in class. I don’t have to worry about that. If I don’t show up in class, I will have cadre of students complaining at the chairman’s office complaining we pay all this tuition and our faculty member is asleep in his office. Having invested huge amount of time learning to see the world through Mexican faculty eyes, to be able to work with them is, I am comfortable doing that. I am probably less comfortable working at the institutional level simply because I am accustomed to rather abrupt changes - who is the president, provost, dean or their equivalent – and you start all over again. There are people that I worked with easily for 25 years , I directed their doctoral dissertation 20 years ago, we published together. It’s a good relationship. Their kid have been up here and stayed at my house. I’ve sent students down there to work on some projects. Those faculty have come up here. That’s cool. And it’s a very productive relationship. So working with colleague sand learning to see the way their institutions work through their eyes greatly helps me when I am here in Portland trying to help our institution understand why assumptions people are making will simply not go anywhere and not be useful. And understanding when there are sometimes – I don’t talk about various dimension of this here simply because I know if I did somebody will say how can we make money out of that and that’s not the point. The point is being able to get access for our students when they are in Mexico. But see that’s seeing it through an academic rather than administrative perspective.

Well I can’t answer institutions in general. But over the years, I’ve done probably in between 60-70 faculty led programs to Mexico and have had in that time period close to a 1000 students or other people participate and I say or others because I’ve done special programs for example, for the Portland police department or high school guidance counselors and have because we opened our two-week intensive program to members of the community who have some reason to go. They’re not just looking for a holiday but people like hotel mangers but health professionals. So we have over time probably had close to 1000 people on programs in Mexico and I look at that as a pretty good track record. That’s a lot of folks. That’s setting up a lot of housing. Doing a lot of visits to the food banks or community museums or other programs. And we’ve had close to 300 Mexican students, faculty, administrators and others up to Portland in part of this kind of notion of reciprocity, obviously it’s not been one-to-one but in that respect, Portland state is far better known in Oaxaca than Oregon state or university of Oregon. Both of them occasional have faculty down there but we’ve had Mexican up here postdoctoral research fellows, getting Ph.D.s and being up here for research on topics such as migration, etc.

The biggest challenges I think I have…for American students going to Mexico we have some residual concerns about safety, although Oaxaca has proven itself to be a far safer place than many other parts of Mexico so some of that has been allayed. For faculty or for institutional context, we’ve been we are okay. We are not having real problems. But it would be nice to not have so much drag in order to get anything done. To get students or faculty up here, obviously, the principal issue aside from financing is visas. Because there is a tendency, and I had experience with this, where they take a look at students from Oaxaca who are the kind of people you would frequently see as undocumented immigrants and the perspective is, you are not really a university student you are going up to go for a job. You are going up for illegal purposes. So that has been a constant challenge, and we have had a number of cases in the last few years in which individuals have been denied visas simply for reasons that are totally unclear. We will have 3 apply and 1 given a visa with no problems, the next will be given a short-term visa and the third will get no visa and if we say if we interchange things, they are exactly the same so dealing with that whether it is in Mexico city and getting through the visa section of the embassy or when one reaches port of entry in the US that’s a major headache. And what it does is it makes Mexican students and some academics about trying, because they make some investments and they may be denied for reasons that are based more on 600 Pennsylvania avenue in DC than anything to do with Mexico.

There has been a continuation. This didn’t start in 2016. But it has clearly become a more difficult…people in Mexico are now not only more sensitive but have become to some degree nervous or I would probably hesitate to say..but people who would have come on programs and visited Oregon in the past are now saying I can also go to Columbia or Canada. We are watching a host of potential graduate students, if they could get the funding, in the past would have come here but now just going to Vancouver, University of Alberta, places in Ontario.. why should we put up with the kind of disdain the Americans offer us when the Canadians are hey come on up.  
I am now actually working with people from Mexico who are at Canadian institutions Working with Mexicans continue but not in Mexico and in the US now in Canada. Working with somebody who graduate from our program who is a Mexican post doc at the University of British Columbia and we are collaborating. Still collaborating with Mexicans but now in a different country.

Personally, I will keep dragging my body south until I can’t make it to the entry of the aircraft. That’s the way it is.  My daughter is Mexican, she was born there and went to school up to junior high. My son spend a lot of time in Mexican and married to Mexican. We have a lot of contacts. That’s the personal side. Institutionally, probably the most important consideration is universities really need – and this is true not just for Mexico but certainly for the Mexico case – to see a lot of this as a part of investment. There has to been a willingness to encourage to departments and faculty, deans, etc. to see all of this in the long term rather than the short term. And the long term could be really long term. I am now going back to some projects and initiatives that I was working on a dozen or 15 years ago that for one reason for another I’ve backed up, people fell out or left, etc. but if you don’t let ideas die and keep contacts alive they can .. an example of this in November of last year the full bright association met in Pueblo Mexico for their annual meeting bringing people from all over. A former full bright from Portland state and I did a presentation there looking at the number of fullbrights that have been generated out of the very first one that I had in 1969 as a graduate student to do my dissertation in Mexico and we have identify at a minimum 19 other full rights who have come from various faculty, student , as a consequence of that initial contact with Mexico. That’s stretching across a life time. The point is that you need to be ready to make these kinds of investments. It has cost me huge amounts of money out of pocket and all kinds of domestic grief from spouse… but you have to be able and willing to make the commitment and fortunately my family said okay we will do it. Everybody is cool with it. That kind of investment continuity is critical, and institutions need to recognize that. It’s not going to be the president who comes back and says I heard this cool thing at the ACE. It’s going to be an investment in time and money over an extended period because that’s what understood in Mexico even though it’s hard to sell here

It is about mutual growth and agreement in certain topics that have concerns from the parties that you are working with and building up the solutions and complete agreement about what are the steps up to, to follow to

Well first defining what the problem is and what are the objectives of working together, for me it is different than an intervention you need to build up relationships with the other party on your own means so once you have started on the peer objectives you need to find that you have the time and resources to work together and finally defining a plan, figuring out what does this collaboration mean and of course you should always have following up and communication and feedback in order to 
Go to the second step, you canít start the second step without having an objective without tracking that evidence of what is needed to validate the work you are doing and with facts in order to prove based on the strengths and weaknesses that you find over the past because realities donít always behave the same

Well I have two major agencies with the University of Guadalajara, one is participating in  problems with reading and writing and which aims to improve the appealing of to improve the habit of reading. We try to make them have a pleasant experience, we plan to work on the effects it makes although there are some concerns in Guadalajara but it made me to have experiences and funds with reading, writing and expression of free speech and we started with a group of a couple hundred in Guadalajara which now we are sustaining groups in public schools of underserved communities for 37,000 kids throughout  the school year. At one area im working with we have an annual meeting which is a result of this to up our percentage and also we bring international stickers and are working with our projects in US and Latin America and my goal there is to organize the major goals and growth of the conference and also in the reading program I partipate in some training with some products that we are generating and because this was the same with the years of social services of senior students and that is proven to sustainable because to leave when they complete the 480 hours of social work and the rotation is very high `so we decided that was our professional work so my job was to develop projects to be approved by the counsel of presidents in the university of Guadalajara and from there we developed a maters program in literacy studies, weíve done some correspondence with some work that is being done at the University of Pennsylvania, actually I established at collaboration and other collaboration with distinguished equity at the University of Georgia and some faculty from California and my own university here in the US which actually started putting a lot of money into the programs. With our collaborations we are strengthening the masters program which started in 2016 establishing coursework and then we worked on then also having international which took about 11 years, in the future we expect we expect to model that and to go across all of the disciplines and it has not just, probably the concern of including reading skills to fix literature and grammar, it is anticipating problem at all levels and and is also just a created to having art and games other activities inside the classroom was a big concern of what this even are interested in with all of the cultures and how these cultures can reach, so we focus on that and the instruction and the weaknesses and we have a very collegial consul so we want to do it but the frustrating thing is to teach how to change the curriculum that mostly in Mexico is teaching centered into more learning centered, having to formulate activities for each unit of learning. You need to have an act of reading an act of writing and and an act of expression that can be aesthetic and act. Based on these principles, we have developed this model, we have a second conference in the last week of November and im also participating in organizing it and it is student to student and reading to reading and writing to writing for us to bring international scholars and give to the community and I also participate as a teacher there Ö and what else do we do? Based on this success, im working with doing this kind of courses that segmented in online format because when I started this activity of developing the masters program at the University of Guajajara and has around 2,016 of our high school students because the university is also committed to providing high school teaching because there were not many high schools in the area in which we were doing some of the work and it has 6 preliminary campuses and 8 regional campuses and there are 167 high schools and 6,000 teachers and probably 98 percent of them are absent so they donít have the time or resources to work there way to here to complete this masters program so we are creating a project called microcredits in which a portion of the classes are provided and they take several sets of courses that they would have to complete to get the diploma and of course it will have some basic transportation to and from during the masters program and we are committed to have them included if they take these courses. Thatís the program for 2019.

At one area im working with we have an annual meeting which is a result of this to up our percentage and also we bring international stickers and are working with our projects in US and Latin America and my goal there is to organize the major goals and growth of the conference and also in the reading program I partipate in some training with some products that we are generating and because this was the same with the years of social services of senior students and that is proven to sustainable because to leave when they complete the 480 hours of social work and the rotation is very high `so we decided that was our professional work so my job was to develop projects to be approved by the counsel of presidents in the university of Guadalajara and from there we developed a maters program in literacy studies, weíve done some correspondence with some work that is being done at the University of Pennsylvania, actually I established at collaboration and other collaboration with distinguished equity at the University of Georgia and some faculty from California and my own university here in the US which actually started putting a lot of money into the programs. With our collaborations we are strengthening the masters program which started in 2016 establishing coursework and then we worked on then also having international which took about 11 years, in the future we expect we expect to model that and to go across all of the disciplines and it has not just, probably the concern of including reading skills to fix literature and grammar, it is anticipating problem at all levels and and is also just a created to having art and games other activities inside the classroom was a big concern of what this even are interested in with all of the cultures and how these cultures can reach, so we focus on that and the instruction and the weaknesses and we have a very collegial consul so we want to do it but the frustrating thing is to teach how to change the curriculum that mostly in Mexico is teaching centered into more learning centered, having to formulate activities for each unit of learning. You need to have an act of reading an act of writing and and an act of expression that can be aesthetic and act. Based on these principles, we have developed this model, we have a second conference in the last week of November and im also participating in organizing it and it is student to student and reading to reading and writing to writing for us to bring international scholars and give to the community and I also participate as a teacher there Ö and what else do we do? Based on this success, im working with doing this kind of courses that segmented in online format because when I started this activity of developing the masters program at the University of Guajajara and has around 2,016 of our high school students because the university is also committed to providing high school teaching because there were not many high schools in the area in which we were doing some of the work and it has 6 preliminary campuses and 8 regional campuses and there are 167 high schools and 6,000 teachers and probably 98 percent of them are absent so they donít have the time or resources to work there way to here to complete this masters program so we are creating a project called microcredits in which a portion of the classes are provided and they take several sets of courses that they would have to complete to get the diploma and of course it will have some basic transportation to and from during the masters program and we are committed to have them included if they take these courses. Thatís the program for 2019.

Funders? Well the university of Guadalajara is in charge of that portion. I donít know but the university itself provides some funds and communicating and that is another part of income at state level but I donít deal with that area. My partner from Guadalajara is the one who arranges everything

No, well I would say there are no funding institutions. The university of Pennsylvania has provided a little bit of funds to pay for the services, the flight and I think 3 or 4 students and University of Guadalajara they pay for the faculty who go there and that is all the funding that we have and the graduate university provided initially some funds for launching the program  and provided a set of books in 2010 and paid for all the traveling for 10 people it was 6 masters students and 5 faculty who were there and that year we made an agreement and we have not had time yet to materialize it into what kind of program collaborative work we are going to mostly because we have been very busy with other things that needed to be completed and at that time of the year we are going to more time to work on some building

Not now, we have not completed other projects. There are people interested in our project at this moment, it has just been conversations the university of name (15:21)  in joining our program and they have sent some students to be trained to understand provided by international faculty that we have brought to the program  like another one from Italy and another from Spain who deals with inclusion and accessibility but I would say there are other political reasons that prevent them to exclude their interests but other political factors that they are not helping in making the initial interest. The national university of Mexico, which is the number one university is also very interested and we have signed an agreement with them and actually our first cohort were there for the last semester learning some ways to teach literacy like semantics because we wanted those students to have those social cultural approach to literacy but a more broad understanding of ways of where they are standing while making those decisions as professionals and the national university provided faculty to organize the courses, they organize the courses, I would say the customize them for us, thus they made it open for other professionals who would be interested in taking these courses and I did a interview in December to see how it went and they were very happy and they want to continue to collaborate with us and they said that our students also bring the other area of literacy. There is also different areas that they have been working with, there is sociocultural programs for literacy that I brought to the University of Guajajara, the only one in the country. So there is a lot of curiosity around how we work and what we teach and what are the results, so  we are writing a group showing our results that is going to be published in the fall and we have linked smaller pieces and making many presentations in conferences but most of them donít create the proceedings so that is work to be done to having a presence in the literature. Another book that is going to be published in Italy about our Mexican model of sociocultural approach to literacy and we hope with these publicans we have a better presence in international educators

Um no, I would say that we are at an interesting moment politically because the university is huge, 14 campuses one university and one chancellor. The chancellor has not changed recently, actually the first week of April is be torn. So whenever there is a new election there is interesting balances power that changes but we are expecting that we will not be effected by it, by the move but the negative factors, we try to spread out our model just to divide in half the teaching and probably without that though we wouldnít have our program registry or national program of quality that is going to be made but if we donít have it, you cant have it until you have some experience now we the first cohort and our students have written books and done international presentations and they have gone to Spain and Argentina and two went two went to Greece for presentation and they have stayed at the national university of Mexico so we hope that we can include this in the program and if that happens then our students would probably have scholarship so they donít have to struggle so they donít have to struggle with the teaching load, so they can not leave it all at the school where they are teaching  and we would have them full time for them to learn about literacy but that is something that is slowing down. The reading load, you cant give as much reading because they have some teaching load at their own institutions those things are little stumps but we are working to solve. There is another major area that is changing our country of the residents of the Mexican change and it is spread between the left and right wing residents about core and core education. However, it is not because of experience or more experience is needed but there are some indications that- national counsel science of and technology wouldnít be as supportive as international students and providing money for research, this counsel was created in 1980 so there is bit of concern about that because we may go into the status of national program of quality of Program but we might now have them for the scholarships of all our students but that is something that we need to wait and see

Well because the Presidnet was there, last July and I went with the faculty who started the program and went with me in 2010 and they were all very clear about it and they advertise it in their slide and they connected over the international literacy program here in the US and they have expressed serval times that they want to continue collaborating but I need to go to California, I need to sit with the president exactly what both sides want and I will say I feel with very different people, with the Guadalajara side so I just need to make the right move at the right time and to make it happen with also the microcredit thing because they wanted that as soon as possible and I am in charge of making all the syllabi and making the feedback and all the organizing that needs to be done, the outline, the instructions assigned because I studied that at Penn State, I learned about the issues that are concerning with a professor who was number one at that time and the editor of the American journal of continuing education  and I have kept up to date so I have established the standards of quality matters and that standard is established, the state of Maryland they mostly are requiring English speaking proficient so they are starting defining that standard and background training so I decided that I would claim the defining in Mexico, who they, well right now I would say since I have interacted with them for work this last year, and they were familiar with some of the points for this standard and quality matters which is very thorough to what is needed for an online course so I need to be supervising all this work and that will continue probably until the summer and see how it goes and then to the President and then have the agreement in Guadalajara. Actually, Iím going to Guadalajara next week, from the 9th to the 16th Iím going to be there. You know, I hope that we build off from that meeting.

Yes so something that probably will have a grand speaker, I will say I have done some grant speaking and I do know that that is really time consuming so I donít do just academic work but to grant speaking too. I think that this well be a very important addition in our project to make it grow to the admissions we have, having international collaborations, and having continuous exchange of students and faculty, people that are Mexican have been enriched by the experience because their ideas and their lives are spread. Some people think that we have not traveled the course, and I would say that the doctorate students think that but many Americans think that Mexicans are not around so when we go and see what we are doing, how we are doing it, I would say has been an expectational experience for them. Also, they grow with noticing that we can make more things with less resources and probably more solidarity also going and experiences different cultures. The Mexicans in my view, we have 40 decision makers, well it was 30 decision makers, faculty, top level faculty, who have earned the status of top researchers in Mexico, and we had 10 students, continuous students, we brought them to the University of Pennsylvania in last October. I would say it is also about being certified but more systemic, organization, things that are done in everyday academic activities. We may solve a problem that is getting all this attention and amount, sometimes we improvise in a sequence right? More systemic and more planned work and action to be taken when all the boxes are in its place. In Mexico sometimes with all this commotion, it is not a consistent work

I would say individualistic probably is that is the main purpose of the culture, I would tell you more solidarity and friendliness an openness is more of a characteristic but because I would say that people are naturally proud of the way they are so an individualistic etiquette  is the person is perceived as a weakness and being so emotional, extraverted, and open and friendly, that is part of being individualistic, it draws the emotional things, the other way around is rational, logical, soft. Self made people donít know what solidarity is, what friendship, they just move just to the scheduled way of what they said they were going to do, and that may create a harsher in the relationship. However, because I have lived in both worlds, I have lived in US for the last quarter century! I know what is going on in the two cultures and I would say having a person like me helps to create bridges and say that you donít need to keep things this way because that is right or even you need to be a little bit more open and to be more accepting and happy and friendly to Mexicans and that makes things easier. I would say an international project has people who understand those cultures, typically in certain projects are made and they bring cultural experts induced Americans and that is more frequent in the US than in Mexico, how to build with cultural, if you were black are gonna seek different paths, if you are a women you are going to taxted with that case or something like that, Americans know that approach because they made us perceive that they are doing social harassment. Those kinds of things, that are superficial cultural knowledge right? You need to understand from the inside what could be some sort of friction and that doesnít happen unless you are first aware if you like that kind of environment and second you have experienced it, in your life and the way you are serving the culture in which you are living right?
